{{Infobox person | name = José Esteban Muñoz | image = JoseMunoz2.jpg | birth_date = August 9, 1967 | birth_place = Havana, Cuba | death_date = December 3, 2013 ({{age|1967|8|9|2013|12|3}} years old) | death_place = New York, NY | occupation = Academic | era = 20th/21st-century Philosophy | known_for = queer theory, race and affect studies, performance studies, ephemera, queer utopia }}
'''José Esteban Muñoz''' (August 9, 1967 – December 3, 2013)<ref name="obit">{{cite web | url=http://www.upress.umn.edu/press/press-releases/highly-regarded-author-and-professor-jose-esteban-munoz-dies | title=Highly regarded author and professor José Esteban Muñoz dies | date=4 December 2013 | accessdate=4 December 2013}}</ref><ref>[http://www.lambdaliterary.org/features/12/04/writer-and-academic-jose-esteban-munoz-has-died/ "Writer and Academic José Esteban Muñoz has Died"]</ref> was a [[Cuban Americans|Cuban American]] academic in the fields of [[performance studies]], [[visual culture]],<ref>{{cite book|title=The art of art history: a critical anthology|year=2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-922984-0|url=https://books.google.com/?id=sDxJK4uGPU8C&pg=PA463&dq=Jos%C3%A9+Esteban+Mu%C3%B1oz+%22visual+culture%22#v=onepage&q=Jos%C3%A9%20Esteban%20Mu%C3%B1oz%20%22visual%20culture%22&f=false|edition=2nd|editor=Donald Preziosi|accessdate=8 February 2011|page=463|quote=...visual culture, none of which are determined in advance, make it possible for us to focus, as José Esteban Muñoz ...}}</ref> [[queer theory]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Driver|first=Susan|title=Queer girls and popular culture: reading, resisting, and creating media|year=2006|publisher=Peter Lang|location=New York|isbn=978-0-8204-7936-1|pages=11|url=https://books.google.com/?id=oO-0q2f9nIgC&pg=PA11&dq=Jos%C3%A9+Esteban+Mu%C3%B1oz+queer#v=onepage&q=jose&f=false}}</ref> [[cultural studies]], and [[critical theory]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Critical theory and performance|year=2006|publisher=Univ. of Michigan|location=Ann Arbor|isbn=978-0-472-06886-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=asORYuvznpQC&pg=PA460&dq=Jos%C3%A9+Esteban+Mu%C3%B1oz+performance+studies#v=onepage&q=munoz&f=false|edition=2. rev.|authors=Roach, Joseph R.|editor=Janelle G. Reinelt|accessdate=8 February 2011|page=403}}</ref> His first book, ''Disidentifications: Queers of Color and the Performance of Politics'' (1999) examines the performance, activism, and survival of queer people of color through the optics of [[performance studies]]. His second book, ''Cruising Utopia: the Then and There of Queer Futurity'', was published by [[New York University Press|NYU Press]] in 2009. Muñoz was Professor in, and former Chair of, the Department of Performance Studies at [[New York University]]'s [[Tisch School of the Arts]].<ref>[http://performance.tisch.nyu.edu/object/MunozJ.html Muñoz: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU]</ref> Muñoz was the recipient of the [[Duke Endowment|Duke Endowment Fellowship]] (1989) and the Penn State University Fellowship (1997).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sca.as.nyu.edu/object/josemunoz|title=José E. Muñoz|website=sca.as.nyu.edu|access-date=2016-04-10}}</ref> He was also affiliated with the [[Modern Language Association]], [[American Studies Association]], and the [[College Art Association]].
==Biography== Muñoz was born in [[Havana]], Cuba in 1967, shortly before relocating with his parents to the [[Cuban exile]] enclave of Hialeah, Florida, the same year. He received his undergraduate education at [[Sarah Lawrence College]] in 1989 with a B.A. in Comparative Literature. In 1994, he completed his doctorate from the Graduate Program in Literature at [[Duke University]], where he studied under the tutelage of queer theorist [[Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick]]. He wrote about artists, performers, and cultural figures including [[Vaginal Davis]], [[Nao Bustamante]], [[Carmelita Tropicana]], [[Isaac Julien]], [[Jorge Ignacio Cortiñas]], [[Kevin Aviance]], [[James Schuyler]], [[Richard Fung]], [[Jean-Michel Basquiat|Basquiat]], [[Pedro Zamora]], and [[Andy Warhol]]. His work is indebted to the work of [[Chicana feminism|Chicana feminists]]: [[Gloria E. Anzaldúa|Gloria Anzaldúa]], [[Cherríe Moraga]], [[Chela Sandoval]], and [[Norma Alarcón]],<ref name=":0" /> members of the [[Frankfurt School]] of critical thinkers such as [[Ernst Bloch]], [[Theodor W. Adorno|Theodor Adorno]], and [[Walter Benjamin]], and the philosophy of [[Martin Heidegger]].
Muñoz died in [[New York City]] in December 2013.<ref name="obit" /><ref name="uminnpressblog">{{cite web| url=http://www.uminnpressblog.com/2013/12/highly-regarded-author-and-professor.html?spref=tw | title=Highly regarded author and professor José Esteban Muñoz dies | accessdate=2013-12-04 }}</ref> He was working on what would have been his third book, ''The Sense of Brown: Ethnicity, Affect and Performance,'' to be published by Durham: [[Duke University Press]]. In addition to his two single authored books, Muñoz co-edited the books ''Pop Out: Queer Warhol'' (1996) with [[Jennifer Doyle]] and Jonathan Flatley and ''Everynight Life: Culture and Dance in Latin/o America'' (1997) with Celeste Fraser Delgado. Along with [[Ann Pellegrini]], José Muñoz was the founding series editor for [[New York University Press|NYU Press]]'s influential Sexual Cultures book series which premiered in 1998. Grounded in [[women of color]] feminism, this book series specializes in titles "that offer alternative mappings of queer life in which questions of race, class, gender, temporality, religion, and region are as central as sexuality" and was foundational to the establishment of queer of color critique.<ref>"Sexual Cultures." ''NYU Press''. Accessed May 17, 2016. <nowiki>http://nyupress.org/series/sexual-cultures/</nowiki>. </ref> Muñoz also worked on the initial Crossing Borders Conference in 1996, which focused on Latin America and Latino queer sexualities.[http://www.boundary2.org/2014/03/the-sense-of-jose/] He was a Board Member of [[City University of New York|CUNY]]'s [[Center for Lesbian and Gay Studies|CLAGS: The Center for LGBTQ Studies]] and editor of the Journal ''[[Social Text]] and Women and Performance: A Journal of Feminist Theory''.<ref name=":6" /> Shortly after his death, CLAGS instituted an award in his honor, given to LGBTQ activists who integrate Queer Studies into their work. The inaugural recipient of the award was [[Janet Mock]] in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Conversation with Janet Mock|url=https://clags.org/event/a-conversation-with-janet-mock/}}</ref> In the Spring of 2016, the Department of Performance Studies at New York University inaugurated the distinguished José Esteban Muñoz Memorial Lecture; speakers have included [[Fred Moten]], José Quiroga, and [[Judith Butler]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tisch.nyu.edu/performance-studies/events-affiliations/jem|title=Annual José Esteban Muñoz Memorial Lecture|last=|first=|date=|website=New York University}}</ref>
== Research and areas of interest == Muñoz challenges and questions contemporary mainstream gay and lesbian politics. He argues that present gay and lesbian politics, whose political goal is [[Gay Rights|gay rights]], [[Same-sex marriage in the United States|same-sex marriage]], and [[Sexual orientation and military service|gays in the military]], are trapped within the limiting normative time and present.<ref name=":8"/> Following [[Ernst Bloch|Ernst Bloch's]], ''The Principle of Hope'', Muñoz is interested in the socially symbolic dimension of certain aesthetic processes that promote [[political idealism]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Muñoz|first=José Esteban|date=2007|title=Cruising the Toilet: LeRoi Jones/Amiri Baraka, Radical Black TRaditions, and Queer Futurity|url=|journal=GLQ: A Journal of Lesbian and Gay Studies|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Muñoz re-articulates queerness as something "not yet here."<ref name=":2" /> Queerness "is that thing that lets us feel that this world is not enough."<ref name=":2" /> Muñoz reconceptualizes queerness from [[identity politics]] and brings it into the field of [[aesthetics]]. For Muñoz, [[Queer aesthetics]], such as the visual artwork of [[Vaginal Davis]], offers a blueprint to map future social relations. Queerness in Muñoz's conceptualization, is a rejection of "straight time", the "here and now" and an insistence of the "then and there."<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Cruising Utopia: The Then and There of Queer Futurity|last=Muñoz|first=Jose Esteban|publisher=NYU Press|year=2009|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Muñoz proposes the concept of "disidentificatory performances," as acts of transgression and creation, by which racial and sexual minorities, or minoritarian subjects articulate the truth about [[cultural hegemony]].<ref name=":2" /> Muñoz critiques [[Lee Edelman]]'s book "No Future" and the concept of queer death drive that results in Muñoz theorization of queer futurity or queer sociality.<ref name=":2" /> Queer futurity thus "illuminates a landscape of possibility for minoritarian subjects through the aesthetic-strategies for surviving and imagining utopian modes of being in the world."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alvarado|first=Leticia|date=July 2015|title="What Comes after Loss?": Ana Mendieta after José|journal=Small Axe |volume=19 |issue=2 |pages=104–110|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Ephemera as evidence === Muñoz first introduced his concept of ephemera as evidence in the 1996 issue of ''Women & Performance: A Journal of Feminist Theory.'' The idea that performance is ephemeral is essential to the field of [[performance studies]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Destination Culture: Tourism, Museums, and Heritage|last=Kirshenblatt-Gimblett|first=Barbara|publisher=University of California Press|year=1998|isbn=|location=Berkeley, CA|pages=}}</ref> In this essay, Muñoz claims that [[Ephemerality|ephemera]] does not disappear.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Perform, Repeat, Record: Live Art in History|last=|first=|publisher=Intellect Books|year=2012|isbn=978-1-84150-489-6|location=|pages=}}</ref> Ephemera in the Muñozian sense, is a modality of "anti-rigor" and "anti-evidence" that reformulates understandings of [[The Materiality Turn|materiality]].<ref name=":5" /> Building on [[Raymond Williams]]' concept of "structures of feeling",<ref>{{Cite book|title=Marxism and Literature|last=Williams|first=Raymond|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1977|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Muñoz claims that the ephemeral, "traces, glimmers, residues, and specks of things," is distinctly material, though not always solid. Framing the performative as both an intellectual and discursive event, he begins by defining queerness as a possibility, a modality, of the social and the relational, a sense of self-knowing. He argues that queerness is passed on surreptitiously due to the fact that the trace of queerness often leaves the queer subject vulnerable for attack.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Muñoz|first=José Esteban|date=1996-01-01|title=Ephemera as Evidence: Introductory Notes to Queer Acts|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/07407709608571228|journal=Women & Performance |volume=8|issue=2|pages=5–16|doi=10.1080/07407709608571228|issn=0740-770X}}</ref> Muñoz's definition of ephemera is influenced by Paul Gilroy's ''The Black Atlantic'' "as part of the exchange of ephemera that connects and makes concert a community."<ref name=":5" /> As a result, Muñoz states, queerness has not been able to exist as "visible evidence" rather it has had to exist in fleeting moments. Thus, queer performances stand as [[evidence]] of queer possibilities and queer worldmaking. Muñoz understands [[Marlon Riggs]]' ''[[Tongues Untied]]'' and ''Black Is, Black Ain't'', as examples of an ephemeral witnessing of Black queer identity. In 2013, Muñoz was a collaborator on the exhibit, ''An Unhappy Archive'' for the [[Brooklyn Museum]]. The goal of the exhibit was to question the normative definition of happiness through the use of texts, posters, books, and drawings. The title of the project is a reference to [[Sara Ahmed]]'s concept of the "unhappy archive." According to Ahmed, the unhappy archive is a collective project rooted in [[Feminist theory|feminist]]-queer and [[Anti-racism|anti-racist]] politics. Other collaborators include [[Ann Cvetkovich]], Karin Michalski, Sabian Baumann, [[Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/feminist_art_base/sabian-baumann|title=Brooklyn Museum: Sabian Baumann|website=www.brooklynmuseum.org|access-date=2016-04-18}}</ref> Muñoz departs from [[Peggy Phelan]]'s argument that the ontology of performance lies in its disappearance.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Unmarked: The Politics of Performance|last=Phelan|first=Peggy|date=1993-02-19|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415068222|edition=1}}</ref> Muñoz parts from this view as it is confined to a narrow view of time. He suggests live performance exists ephemerally then without completely disappearing after it vanishes.<ref name=":8" />
=== Disidentification === Muñoz's theory of disidentification builds on [[Michel Pêcheux]]'s understanding of disidentification and subject formation by examining how minoritarian subjects, those whose identities render them a minority (i.e. [[queer]] [[people of color]]), negotiate identity in a majoritarian world that punishes, and attempts to erase the existence of, those who do not fit the normative subject (i.e.[[Heterosexuality|heterosexual]], [[cisgender]], [[White people|white]], [[middle class]], [[male]]). Muñoz notes how queer people of color, as a result of the effects of [[colonialism]] have been placed outside dominant racial and sexual ideology, namely white normativity<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ward|first=Jane|date=2008-09-01|title=White Normativity: The Cultural Dimensions of Whiteness in a Racially Diverse LGBT Organization|url=http://spx.sagepub.com/content/51/3/563|journal=Sociological Perspectives|volume=51|issue=3|pages=563–586|doi=10.1525/sop.2008.51.3.563|issn=0731-1214}}</ref> and [[heteronormativity]]. In his own words, "disidentification is about managing and negotiating historical trauma and systemic violence."<ref name=":0" /> The disidentificatory subject does not assimilate (identify) nor reject (counter identify) dominant ideology. Rather, the disidentificatory subject employs a third strategy,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pérez|first=Emma|date=2003-01-01|title=Queering the Borderlands: The Challenges of Excavating the Invisible and Unheard|jstor=3347351|journal=Frontiers: A Journal of Women Studies|volume=24|issue=2/3|pages=122–131}}</ref> and, "tactically and simultaneously works on, with, and against, a cultural form."<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Disidentifications: Queers of Color and the Performance of Politics|last=Muñoz|first=José Esteban|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|year=1999|isbn=978-0-8166-3015-8|location=Minnesota|pages=}}</ref> Aside from being a process of identification,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Case|first=Sue‐Ellen|last2=Abbitt|first2=Erica Stevens|date=2004-03-01|title=Disidentifications, Diaspora, and Desire: Questions on the Future of the Feminist Critique of Performance|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.1086/380627|journal=Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society|volume=29|issue=3|pages=925–938|doi=10.1086/380627|issn=0097-9740}}</ref> disidentification is also a survival strategy.<ref name=":0" /> Through disidentification, the disidentifying subject is able to rework the cultural codes of the mainstream to read themselves into the mainstream,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shaked|first=Nizan|date=2008-01-01|title=Phantom Sightings: Art after the Chicano Movement|jstor=40068561|journal=American Quarterly|volume=60|issue=4|pages=1057–1072}}</ref> a simultaneous insertion and subversion. By the mode of disidentification, queer subjects are directed towards the future. Through the use of shame and "misrecognition through failed [[Interpellation (philosophy)|interpellation]], queer collectivity neither assimilates nor strictly opposes the dominant regime," but works on strategies that result in queer counterpublics.<ref name=":2" />
His theory on disidentification is foundational to understandings of queer of color performance art and has proved indispensable across a wide variety of disciplines. Muñoz's argument is in conversation with [[Stefan Brecht]]'s theory on "queer theater." Brecht argues that queer theater inevitably turns into humor and passive repetition, ultimately, falling apart.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Queer Theatre, The original theatre of the City of New York, From the mid-60s to the mid-70s, Book 2.|last=Brecht|first=Stefan|publisher=New York/London: Methuen|year=1986|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Muñoz, is weary of Brecht's theory as it doesn't seem to consider the work of artists of color and also ignores the use of humor as a didactic and political project.<ref name=":0" /> Muñoz argues that the work of queer artists of color is political and will remain political as long as the logic of dominant ideology exists.
=== Counterpublics === In ''Disidentifications,'' Muñoz defines counterpublics as "communities and relational chains of resistance that contest the dominant public sphere."<ref name=":0" /> Counterpublics have the capacity of world-making through a series of cultural performances that disidentify with the normative scripts of [[whiteness]], [[Heteronormativity|heternormativity]], and [[misogyny]].<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/7538901/Locating_Hope_and_Futurity_in_the_Anticipatory_Illumination_of_Queer_Performance._Book_review_of_Jos%25C3%25A9_Mu%25C3%25B1oz_s_Cruising_Utopia_the_Then_and_There_of_Queer_Futurity|title=Locating Hope and Futurity in the Anticipatory Illumination of Queer Performance. Book review of José Muñoz's Cruising Utopia: the Then and There of Queer Futurity|website=www.academia.edu|access-date=2016-05-05}}</ref> Counterpublics disrupt social scripts and create through their work an opening of possibility for other visions of the world that map different, utopian social relations.<ref name=":2" /> Muñoz suggests that such work is vital for queer people of color subjects survival and possibilities for another world.<ref name=":2" /> At the center of counterpublic performances is the idea of educated hope, "which is both critical affect and methodology."<ref name=":8"/> [[Jack Halberstam]] in the book ''In a Queer Time & Place,'' discusses the role of [[Drag king]] culture as a form of counterpublics that validate and produce "minoritarian public spheres" at the same time they challenge white [[heteronormativity]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=In a Queer Time and Place: Transgender Bodies, Subcultural LIves|last=Halberstam|first=Judith "Jack"|publisher=NYU Press|year=2005|isbn=|location=|pages=128}}</ref> Examples of counterpublics includes visual performances like Xandra Ibarra "La Chica Boom" spictacles,<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://hemisphericinstitute.org/hemi/en/enc14-trasnocheo/item/2467-enc14-trasnocheo-ibarra-spictacle|title=La Chica Boom|website=hemisphericinstitute.org|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref> [[Vaginal Davis]], and Cuban [[Activism|activist]] and [[The Real World: San Francisco]] cast-member, [[Pedro Zamora]].
=== Cruising utopia === In Cruising Utopia, José Muñoz develops a critical methodology of hope to question the present and open up the future. He draws on Ernst Bloch's Marxist inspired analysis of hope, [[temporality]], and [[utopia]], and looks at "inspirational moments from the past in order to (re)imagine the future."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mediationsjournal.org/articles/queer-principles-of-hope|title=Review of Cruising Utopia: The Then and There of Queer Futurity : Mediations : Journal of the Marxist Literary Group|website=www.mediationsjournal.org|access-date=2016-05-05}}</ref> In the book, Muñoz revisits a series of queer art works from the past to envision the political potentiality within them. He draws on the queer work of [[Frank O'Hara]], [[Andy Warhol]], [[Fred Herko]], [[Amiri Baraka|LeRoi Jones]], [[Ray Johnson]], [[Jill Johnston]], Jack Smith, [[James Schuyler|James Schulyer]], [[Elizabeth Bishop]] and [[Samuel R. Delany|Samuel Delany's]] and [[Eileen Myles]] queer memoirs of the 60s and 70s.<ref name=":8"/> Muñoz develops a hermeneutics of "trace and residue to read the mattering of these works, their influence and world-making capacity."<ref name=":8"/> This world-making capacity allows for a queer futurity. Muñoz develops an argument for about queerness as horizon, hope, and futurity.<ref name=":8"/>
Queer futurity is a literary and queer cultural theory that combines elements of [[utopia]]nism, [[historicism]], [[Speech act|speech act theory]], and [[Ideal (ethics)|political idealism]] in order to critique the present and current dilemmas faced by [[queer people of color]], but also to revise, interrogate, and re-examine the [[death drive]] in [[queer theory]]. Queer futurity or "queer sociability" addresses themes and concerns of minoritarian subjects through a [[performance]] and [[aesthetics]] lens, encompassing a range of media and artists with a shared interest in envisioning queer futures that stem from minoritarian subject experiences. According to [[Fred Moten]], "Jose's queerness is a utopian project whose temporal dimensionality is manifest not only as projection into the future but also as projection of a certain futurity into and onto the present and the past."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boundary2.org/2014/03/the-beauty-of-jose-esteban-munoz/|title=The Beauty of José Esteban Muñoz {{!}} boundary 2|last=boundary2|website=www.boundary2.org|access-date=2016-05-05}}</ref> Queerness also has a spatial dimension, "insofar as it is located in displacement" such as virtual chats, disappearing clubs, gentrified neighborhoods and venues, to name a few.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boundary2.org/2014/03/the-beauty-of-jose-esteban-munoz/|title=The Beauty of José Esteban Muñoz {{!}} boundary 2|last=boundary2|website=www.boundary2.org|access-date=2016-05-06}}</ref> The study of queer sociability has expanded beyond the fields of [[Performance studies|Performance Studies]], [[Queer theory|Queer Theory]], and [[Gender and Women Studies]] and has been used by various scholars to address issues of [[Black Diaspora Studies]],<ref>{{Cite book|title=Territories of the Soul|last=Ellis|first=Nadia|publisher=Duke University Press|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> [[Caribbean Studies]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boundary2.org/2014/03/listening-ephemerality-and-queer-fidelity/|title=Listening, Ephemerality, and Queer Fidelity|last=Stadler|first=Gustavus|date=March 10, 2016|website=boundary2.org|publisher=The B2 Review|access-date=}}</ref> and [[Musicology|musicolog]]<nowiki/>y.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boundary2.org/2014/03/listening-ephemerality-and-queer-fidelity/|title=Listening, Ephemerality, and Queer Fidelity {{!}} boundary 2|last=boundary2|website=www.boundary2.org|access-date=2016-05-06}}</ref> The elements of queer sociability has not only created the field of [[queer of color critique]] but has been the center of special journal issues such as the Virtual Special Issue: José Esteban Muñoz.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://explore.tandfonline.com/page/ah/rwap-vsi|title=Virtual Special Issue: José Esteban Muñoz|last=|first=|date=|website=Queer Acts|publisher=Women & Performance: A Journal of Feminist Theory|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Chusma === Muñoz theorizes chusmeria or chusma, as a form of behavior that is in excess of normative comportment. Chusmeria is "a form of behavior that refuses bourgeois comportment and suggests Latinos should not be too black, too poor, or too sexual, among other characteristics that exceed normativity."<ref name=":4" /> Queer theorist Deborah Vargas uses chusmeria to inform her theory of ''lo sucio'', "the dirty, nasty, and filthy" of society.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Vargas|first=Deborah|date=|title=Ruminations of Lo Sucio as a Latino Queer Analytic|url=|journal=American Quarterly |volume=66 |issue=3 |doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> In the Muñozian sense, "lo sucio" persistently lingers as the "yet to be".
=== Sense of feeling brown === Muñoz began to theorize on brown affect in his piece "Feeling Brown: Ethnicity and Affect" in Ricardo Bracho's ''The Sweetest Hangover'' (and Other STDs). In this article, Muñoz wanted to focus on ethnicity, affect, and performance in order to question the U.S. national affect and highlight the affective struggles that keep minoritatrian subjects from accessing normative identity politics.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Muñoz|first=José Esteban Muñoz|date=2000|title=Feeling Brown: Ethnicity and Affect in Ricardo Bracho's "The Sweetest Hangover (And Other STDS)|url=|journal=Theatre Journal |volume=52 |issue=1 |pages=67–79|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Muñoz undertaking was to move beyond notions of ethnicity as "what people are" and instead understand it as a performative "what people do."<ref name=":1" /> Muñoz describes how race and ethnicity are to be understood as "affective" differences.<ref name=":1" /> Affective differences are the "ways in which different historically coherent groups 'feel' differently and navigate the material world on a different emotional register."<ref name=":6" /> In the piece "Feeling Brown", Muñoz discussed the notion of racial performativity as a form of political doing based on the recognition of the effects of race. Thus, "feeling brown" is a modality of recognizing the affective particularities coded to specific historical subjects, like the term [[Latino (demonym)|Latina]]. He emphasized that Brown feelings "are not individualized affective particularity" but rather is a collective mapping of self and others.<ref name=":1" /> The turn from identity to affect resulted in Muñoz coneptualization of the "Brown Commons" as the key point in which race is experienced as a feeling, as an affective specificity. Licia Fiol-Matta describes Jose's "Cubanity" as a "disidentity, a feeling brown, part of a brown undercommons and as an artistic manifestation of the sense of brown."<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.boundary2.org/2014/03/the-sense-of-jose/|title=The Sense of José {{!}} boundary 2|last=boundary2|website=www.boundary2.org|access-date=2016-05-05}}</ref> With Latinidad as an affective difference, "José gave us a road map or toolkit to point us in the direction of the gap, wound, or hole of displacement as a necessary condition for interpretation to take place."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boundary2.org/2014/03/the-sense-of-jose/|title=The Sense of José {{!}} boundary 2|last=boundary2|website=www.boundary2.org|access-date=2016-05-06}}</ref>
== Influence and impact == After his death, a special issue of the journal ''Boundary 2'', themed "The Beauty of José Esteban Muñoz", was published. The journal featured pieces from various scholars influenced by Muñoz including [[Juana María Rodríguez]], [[Fred Moten]], [[Daphne Brooks]], Elizabeth Freeman, [[Jack Halberstam]], and [[Ann Cvetkovich]]. The issue covered themes related to Muñoz's contribution to various academic fields such as queer of color critique, affect studies, and the new ways to conceptualized concepts such as Latina/o identity, queer ephemera, and [[temporality]]. After Muñoz's death, various art, literary,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lambdaliterary.org/features/rem/12/04/writer-and-academic-jose-esteban-munoz-has-died/|title=Writer and Academic José Esteban Muñoz has Died|last=Johnson|first=William|date=December 4, 2013|website=Features : Remembrances : Article|publisher=Lambada Literary|access-date=}}</ref> and academic institutions,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bcrw.barnard.edu/remembering-jose-esteban-munoz/|title=Remembering Jose Esteban Muñoz|last=|first=|date=|website=Barnard Center for Research on Women|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> artists,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://punctumbooks.com/uncategorized/coke-jose-esteban-munoz-1966-2013/|title=Having a Coke With You: For José Esteban Munoz (1966-2013)|last=Joy|first=Eileen|date=December 6, 2013|website=Punctum Books|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> and periodicals,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/nytimes/obituary.aspx?pid=168446748|title=Jose Munoz Obituary|last=|first=|date=December 10, 2013|work=|access-date=|via=}}</ref> commemorated his legacy and contributions through a series of online<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hyperallergic.com/96713/queer-theorist-jose-esteban-munoz-dead-at-46/|title=Queer Theorist José Esteban Muñoz Dead at 46|last=Heddaya|first=Mostafa|date=December 4, 2013|website=Hyperallergic|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latintimes.com/jose-esteban-munoz-dies-queer-theorist-dead-46-135707|title=José Esteban Muñoz Dies: Queer Theorist Dead At 46|last=Lopez|first=Oscar|date=December 4, 2013|website=|publisher=Latin Times|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bullybloggers.wordpress.com/2013/12/06/jose-esteban-munoz-1966-2013/|title=Jose Esteban Muñoz 1967-2013|last=|first=|date=|website=Bully Bloggers|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://allegralaboratory.net/remembering-jose-esteban-munoz-rip/|title=Remembering José Esteban Muñoz – RIP|date=2013-12-23|website=Allegra |access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/obituaries/94506872/memory-jose-e-munoz-making-queer-future|title=In Memory of Jose E. Munoz: Making Queer Future|website=connection.ebscohost.com|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref> and journal based obituaries<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Halberstam|first=Jack|date=2014-06-01|title=Obituary: José Esteban Muñoz, 1967-2013|url=http://sex.sagepub.com/content/17/4/501|journal=Sexualities|volume=17|issue=4|pages=501–502|doi=10.1177/1363460714534357|issn=1363-4607}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://socialtextjournal.org/remembering-jose-munoz/|title=Remembering José Esteban MuñozSocial Text|website=socialtextjournal.org|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref> and memorial lectures and annual events.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tisch.nyu.edu/performance-studies/events/FredMotenLecture|title=The Blur and Breathe Books: A Lecture by Fred Moten|last=Moten|first=Fred|date=February 24, 2016|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://lareviewofbooks.org/article/vacating-now-remembering-jose-esteban-munoz|title=Vacating The Here and Now For a There and Then: Remembering José Esteban Muñoz|last=Colucci|first=Emily|date=March 31, 2014|website=LA Review of Books|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> In the special edition of ''Boundary 2'', Ann Cvetkovich credits Muñoz for the explosion and morphing of the field of affect theory as a result of Jose's work. Deborah Paredez describes Muñoz as key to the practice of a critical and ethical attentiveness to a wide range of performances by Latina/o artists and for helping scholars listen to the melody of what is like to feel brown.
In 2014, Muñoz's concept of ''ephemera as evidence'' was the theme for a Visual AIDS exhibit,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.visualaids.org/events/detail/ephemera-as-evidence-visual-aids-exhibition|title=Ephemera As Evidence|last=AIDS|first=Visual|website=Visual AIDS|access-date=2016-04-09}}</ref> curated by Joshua Lubin-Levy and Ricardo Montez. The exhibit took its name from Muñoz's 1996 essay, ''Ephemera as Evidence: Introductory Notes to Queer Acts''. Featuring [[Visual arts|visual art]], [[performance art]], and [[Pedagogy|pedagogical]] projects, ''Ephemera as Evidence'' explores how the [[HIV/AIDS]] crisis forged new relationships of [[temporality]]. The exhibit, which ran from June 5 to June 24 at La Mama Galleria, featured works from [[Nao Bustamante]], [[Carmelita Tropicana]], Benjamin Fredrickson, and more.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://artforum.com/index.php?pn=picks&id=47279&view=print|title="Ephemera as Evidence" - artforum.com / critics' picks|website=artforum.com|access-date=2016-04-21}}</ref>
Muñoz's disidentification theory has also influenced other thinkers in the field. In ''Crip Theory: Cultural Signs of Queerness and Disability,'' Robert McRuer, draws on Muñoz's theory of disidentification to articulate and imagine "collective disidentifications" made possible when putting queer and crip theory in conversation.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Crip Theory: Cultural Signs of Queerness and Disability|last=McRuer|first=Robert|publisher=NYU Press|year=2006|isbn=978-0-8147-5713-0|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> [[Diana Taylor (professor)|Diana Taylor]],<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Archive and the Repertoire: Performing Cultural Memory in the Americas|last=Taylor|first=Diana|publisher=Duke University Press|year=2003|isbn=978-0-8223-8531-8|location=Durham, North Carolina|pages=}}</ref> [[Ann Cvetkovich]],<ref>{{Cite book|title=Depression: A Public Feeling|last=Cvetkovich|first=Ann|publisher=Duke University Press|year=2012|isbn=0-8223-5238-9|location=Durham, North Carolina|pages=}}</ref> [[Roderick Ferguson]],<ref>{{Cite book|title=Aberrations in Black: Toward a Queer of Color Critique|last=Ferguson|first=Roderick A.|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|year=2004|isbn=978-0816641291|location=Minneapolis, Minnesota|pages=}}</ref> and [[Jack Halberstam]]<ref>{{Cite book|title=In a Queer Time and Place: Transgender Bodies, Subcultural Lives|last=Halberstam|first=Jack|publisher=NYU Press|year=2005|isbn=978-0-8147-3584-8|location=New York, New York|pages=}}</ref> have cited and applied Muñoz to their own work. Muñoz was also influential to the field of Queer of Color Critique. In the book ''Aberrations in Black'', Roderick Ferguson employs Muñoz's disidentification theory to reveal how the discourses of [[Human sexuality|sexuality]] are used to articulate theories of racial difference in the field of [[sociology]]. Moreover, disidentification theory has been used by an array of scholars to apply a queer of color critique to various themes such as [[identity politics]], [[queer temporality]], [[homonationalism]], and diaspora and native studies.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Smith|first=Andrea|date=2010|title=QUEER THEORY AND NATIVE STUDIES The Heteronormativity of Settler Colonialism|url=|journal=GLQ: A Journal of Lesbian and Gay Studies |volume=16 |issue=1–2 |pages=41–68|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2014, the art collective, [[My Barbarian]], was selected to participate in "Alternate Endings",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/album/3139847|title=ALTERNATE ENDINGS videos on Vimeo|website=vimeo.com|access-date=2016-04-27}}</ref> a video program put on by Visual AIDS, for the 25th anniversary of [[Day Without Art|Day With(out) Art]]. Begun in 1989, the annual event is meant to commemorate the AIDS crisis and give artists a platform to display work that reflects and responds to the history of HIV/AIDS. Titled, "Counterpublicity", the video performance is based on Muñoz's essay on [[Pedro Zamora]].<ref name=":0" /> In the embodied performance, the three artists recreate scenes from [[The Real World: San Francisco]] in an exaggerated manner, critically examining the politics of [[reality television]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/108349379|title=My Barbarian - Counterpublicity (2014)|website=Vimeo|access-date=2016-04-27}}</ref> Lyrics for the piece were adapted from Muñoz's theory of counterpublic spheres. In a panel, My Barbarian said, "the video is a remembrance within a remembrance: to Pedro Zamora and to José Esteban Muñoz."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.visualaids.org/blog/detail/tavia-nyongo#_edn3|title=The video is a remembrance within a remembrance: to Pedro Zamora and to José Esteban Muñoz.|last=AIDS|first=Visual|website=Visual AIDS|access-date=2016-04-27}}</ref> The video premiered at Outfest in Los Angeles.
[[Xandra Ibarra]], La Chica Boom use of "spics" is influenced by Muñoz's Sense of Brown and Counterpublics. For Muñoz, spics are epithets linked to questions of affect and excess affect. Ibarra's performances of "la Virgensota Jota" and "La tortillera"<ref name=":3" /> are ways to re-inhabit toxic languages for the purpose of remapping the social or what Muñoz described as disidentificatory performances.<ref name=":1" /> Muñoz has seminal influence on many American scholars and artists, among them Robert McRuer, [[Roderick Ferguson]], [[Daphne Brooks]], Nadia Ellis, [[Juana María Rodríguez]], [[Deborah Paredez]], and [[Ann Cvetkovich]].

revision.text:
'''Karl Barth's views on Mary''' agreed with much [[Roman Catholic]] dogma but disagreed with the Catholic veneration of [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Mary]]. [[Karl Barth|Barth]], a leading 20th-century theologian, was a [[Reformed Protestant]]. Aware of the common dogmatic tradition of the early Church, Barth fully accepted the dogma of Mary as the [[Mother of God]]. Through Mary, Jesus belongs to the human race. Through Jesus, Mary is Mother of God.
==Background==
===Theology of Karl Barth=== Karl Barth (May 10, 1886 – December 10, 1968) a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[Reformed]] theologian, was one of the most important Christian thinkers of the 20th century. Beginning with his experience as a pastor, he rejected the predominant [[liberal Christianity|liberal]] theology typical of 19th-century [[Protestantism]], especially [[Germany|German]], and instead embarked on a unique theological path, often labelled [[neo-orthodoxy]] by critics (a label emphatically rejected by Barth himself), that emphasized the sovereignty of God particularly through his innovative doctrine of [[predestination|election]]. Barth's theology swept through Europe and Britain.
Barth was originally trained in German [[Protestantism|Protestant]] [[Liberal Christianity|Liberalism]] under such teachers as [[Wilhelm Herrmann]], but reacted against this theology at the time of the [[World War I|First World War]]. His reaction was fed by several factors, including his commitment to the German and Swiss [[International League of Religious Socialists|Religious Socialist]] movement surrounding men like [[Hermann Kutter]], the influence of the [[Biblical Realism]] movement surrounding men like [[Christoph Blumhardt]] and [[Søren Kierkegaard]], and the impact of the [[skepticism|skeptical philosophy]] of [[Franz Overbeck]].
===Epistle to the Romans=== In his commentary ''[[The Epistle to the Romans]]'' (Ger. ''Der Römerbrief''; particularly in the thoroughly re-written second edition of 1922) Barth argued that the God who is revealed in the cross of [[Jesus]] challenges and overthrows any attempt to ally God with human cultures, achievements, or possessions. Many theologians believe this work to be the most important theological treatise since [[Friedrich Schleiermacher]]'s ''[[On Religion: Speeches to its Cultured Despisers]].''
In the decade following the First World War, Barth was linked with a number of other theologians, actually very diverse in outlook, who had reacted against their teachers' liberalism, in a movement known as "[[Dialectical Theology]]" <ref>(Ger. ''Dialektische Theologie'').</ref> Other members of the movement included [[Rudolf Bultmann]], [[Eduard Thurneysen]], [[Emil Brunner]], and [[Friedrich Gogarten]].
==Marian views==
===The nativity mystery===
* ''The nativity mystery “conceived from the [[Holy Spirit]] and born from the [[Virgin Mary]]”, means, that God became human, truly human out of his own grace. The miracle of the existence of Jesus , his “climbing down of God” is: Holy Spirit and Virgin Mary! Here is a human being, the Virgin Mary, and as he comes from God, Jesus comes also from this human being. Born of the Virgin Mary means a human origin for God. Jesus Christ is not only truly God, he is human like every one of us. He is human without limitation. He is not only similar to us, he is like us''.<ref>Barth, Dogmatik im Grundriss, 1947, 125,127</ref>
This means to Barth, God's presence in our world, His presence as man among men and therefore God's revelation to humanity. It also means humanity's reconciliation with God. To Barth, this happened and still happens, it is the substance of the Christmas message.
This God is conceived where we all are conceived. He is born of Mary. She who conceived and bore Him, plays our part in the wonder of Christmas, for it concerns us. God has come to us. "Disguised in our flesh and blood, is the Eternal God."
=== Virgin Birth === The [[Nicene Creed]] says: ''Et incarnatus est de Spiritu Sancto ex Maria virgine et homo factus est'' ("and he [God the Son] became body from the Virgin Mary and was made man"). In Barth's theology – in contrast to much of the contemporary liberal theology – this statement is interpreted to mean the [[dogma]] of the [[Virgin birth of Jesus|Virgin Birth]]. It means that Jesus as a human does not have a father, in the same way that as the Son of God he has no mother. The Holy Spirit, through whom Mary conceived, is not just any spirit, it is God himself whose act must be understood spiritually and not physically.<ref>Barth, Kirchliche Dogmatic I, 2, 219</ref> Mary is "full of grace" according to Barth, but this grace is not earned but totally given to her. This is quite similar to Catholic teaching, in which Mary, "by sheer grace," received the fullness of grace from God at the moment of her conception, that she might give her consent at the annunciation.<ref>Catechism of the Catholic Church, 722</ref> Barth argues that the Church adopted its doctrine of the [[perpetual virginity of Mary]] not because of Mary, but in defence of its [[Christology]].
=== Mother of God ===
Karl Barth states that as a Christian and theologian, he does not reject the description of Mary as the "Mother of God." To him, this is a legitimate expression of Christological truth. The description of Mary as the "Mother of God" was and is sensible, permissible and necessary as an auxiliary Christological proposition.<ref>Church Dogmatics, I, 2, Edinburgh: T. & T. Clark, 1963, 138)</ref><ref name="Barth2004-1">{{cite book|author=Karl Barth|title=Church Dogmatics: The doctrine of the word of God (2 pts.)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Po0rhLSFx0wC&pg=PA138|date=1 January 2004|publisher=Continuum|isbn=978-0-567-05069-4|pages=138–}}</ref>
===Critique of the Catholic view === Barth on the other hand sees the term "Mother of God," as "being overloaded by the so-called Mariology of the Roman Catholic Church".<ref>Church Dogmatics, 138</ref> He considered the Roman Catholic veneration of Mary a terrible mistake and heresy.
* ''Where ever Mary is venerated, and devotion to her takes place, there the Church of Christ does not exist''.<ref>Barth, Kirchliche Dogmatik, I, 2, 154</ref><ref name="Barth2010">{{cite book|author=Karl Barth|title=Church Dogmatics Study Edition 3: The Doctrine of the Word of God I.2 § 13-15|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=APXR1E0m_AkC&pg=PA145|date=2 September 2010|publisher=Continuum|isbn=978-0-567-02766-5|pages=145–}}</ref> * ''Mariology is an excrescence, i.e., a diseased construct of theological thought. Excrescences must be excised.'' <ref>Barth, Kirchliche Dogmatik, I, 2, 153</ref><ref name="Barth2004">{{cite book|author=Karl Barth|title=Church Dogmatics: The doctrine of the word of God (2 pts.)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Po0rhLSFx0wC&pg=PA139|date=1 January 2004|publisher=Continuum|isbn=978-0-567-05069-4|pages=139–}}</ref>
He warns however, of extending this critique too far: {{quote|It is not recommended that we should base our repudiation [of Marian doctrine] on the assertion that there has taken place here an irruption from the heathen sphere, an adoption of the idea, current in many non-Christian religions, of a more or less central and original female or mother deity. In dogmatics you can establish everything and nothing from parallels from the history of religions.<ref>Church Dogmatics, Vol. 1, p. 143).</ref>}}
And, Barth equally attacks Protestant theology on this issue: "For justice sake, one has to say, that the Protestant rejection of Roman Catholic mariology and Marian cult is dishonest, as long as Protestantism is caught in the same unreal problem".<ref>Barth, Kirchliche Dogmatic, I,2,160</ref> He was a close friend of [[Hans Urs von Balthasar]], who published about him. Barth’s dogmatic theology was partly based on [[Thomas Aquinas]], although he departed from Aquinas on many characteristically Catholic points.
==See also== * [[Blessed Virgin Mary]] * [[Theotokos]] * [[Marian doctrines of the Catholic Church|Marian doctrines of the Roman Catholic Church]] * [[Mariology (Roman Catholic)]]
==Sources == * Karl Barth, ''Die kirchliche Dogmatik,'' Zollikon, Vol.I-IV, 1932-1955

page.title: Leigh’s Political Women and Women’s Suffrage Activism

revision.text:
{{notability|date=March 2018}}
This is an overview of '''Women's Suffrage activism and local politics''' as experienced in [[Leigh, Lancashire]] between 1900 and 1914.
== 1900 to 1909 ==
In October 1900 Mrs A Urmston of the Leigh Co-operative Women's Guild,<ref>Leigh Cooperative Women's Guild Monthly Reports. Wigan Archives Leigh Town Hall.</ref> wrote to Leigh's MP, [[C. P. Scott]] asking him to vote favourably on Women's Suffrage Bills. He answered in the affirmative.<ref>Guardian Archive, Women's Suffrage collection GDN/123/54 and 55 Archive + Manchester</ref> In 1908 [[Henry Yorke Stanger]], Leigh County Court Judge and MP for [[Kensington North]], introduced a private member's Women's Suffrage Bill.<ref>Hansard February 1908 on line</ref><ref>Leigh Journal 2 September 1910</ref>
On 15 July 1909, [[Women's Social and Political Union]] activists, [[Annie Kenney]], [[Jennie Baines]], [[Mabel Capper]], [[Charlotte Marsh]] and [[Florence Clarkson]] attempted to force their way into Leigh Co-operative Hall to disrupt the Liberal Party's guest speaker, [[Lewis Harcourt]].<ref>Leigh Journal 16 July 1909</ref> After a violent struggle, Clarkson of Oxford Road, Manchester was arrested and bailed at £10.<ref>Leigh Journal 16 July 1909 Wigan Archives Leigh Town Hall</ref> The next day when tried in Leigh Police Station's Day Room,<ref>Leigh Journal 16 July 1909 Wigan Archives Leigh Town Hall</ref> she refused to pay the 20 [[shilling]] fine imposed and was sentenced to fourteen days in the second division at [[Strangeways]] Gaol in Manchester.<ref>Borough of Leigh Court Register Volume 3 16 July 1909</ref> There she went on [[hunger strike]] but did not serve her full sentence without food, denying herself food for 65 hours.<ref>Leigh Chronicle 6 August 1909</ref>
== National Union of Women’s Suffrage Societies ==
During the General Election of January 1910, members of the [[National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies]] (NUWSS) visited Leigh to collect signatures for their Voters’ Petition.<ref>Leigh Chronicle 28 January 1910 Wigan Archives Leigh Town Hall</ref> They aimed to prove that male voters were in favour of votes for women. With the cooperation of local suffragists, 2,843 signatures were collected at Leigh polling stations.<ref>Manchester Archive + M50 Women's Suffrage Collection Reel 3</ref> After which, a banner stating "2,843 Men of Leigh Demand Women’s Suffrage" was used to advertise suffrage meetings in the town.<ref>Elizabeth Crawford, Women's Suffrage Movement:A Reference Guide</ref> A similar banner, bearing the same legend was used in the "Prison to Citizenship Constitutional Demonstration" in London on 18 June 1910.<ref>British Pathe News: Various Suffrage Material Religion, Politics, Trade and Industry stills 137,138,139</ref>
From September 1910 the [[North of England Society for Women's Suffrage]] began a consciousness raising campaign in Leigh.<ref>National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies</ref> In October 1910 the Leigh branch of the NUWSS, the Leigh Women’s Suffrage Society, was formed. Its first secretary was Miss F.P. Hindshaw BA,<ref>National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies Women's Suffrage Collection M50 Reel 3 Manchester Archives +</ref> followed by Miss L. Cook of 13 Railway Road.<ref>National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies Women's Suffrage Collection M50 Reel 3 Manchester Archives </ref> Membership of the Leigh branch was not gendered and non party. The campaign took the form of a series of public meetings and debates led by prominent pro-suffrage workers, supported by local interested parties and out of town speakers, including the Liberal Association President, and editor and proprietor of the Manchester Guardian, C.P. Scott. Other key speakers included Mrs F.T. Swanwick, suffragist and editor of the NUWSS paper the [[Common Cause]]: [[Kathleen Courtney]], secretary of the North of England Society for Women’s Suffrage; Lisbeth Simms of the Women’s Labour League; Margaret Robertson BA Manchester Society/NUWSS organiser: and a Manchester councillor, [[Margaret Ashton]], founder member of the Women’s Trade Union League and chairperson of the NUWSS. The women spoke on why women needed and deserved the vote whilst attempting to discredit opponents' arguments. They stressed their non militancy, non party and law abiding credentials to address a degree of fear by women of becoming identified with the "shrieking sisterhood" (WSPU). Locally there were immediate and legitimate reasons for unease and fear. When Margaret Robertson spoke at a [[National Union of Teachers]] Association meeting in Leigh, some male members in the audience "moodily twirled their moustaches and gazed at the floor" and the chairman "kept a few from that energy of opposition that often ends in blows".<ref>Leigh Journal 6 November 1911 Wigan Archives Leigh Town Hall</ref> This latent aggression on occasion resulted in violence, and in one instance was condoned by the local press. When a socialist in Tyldesley was mobbed for hanging out a ‘Votes for Women’ banner, Leigh Chronicle opined "he asked for it" and "deserved what he got".<ref>Leigh Chronicle 1913 Wigan Archives Leigh Town Hall</ref>
== Political associations==
A proportion of the town's women had organised into political associations before the campaign. The Leigh Women’s Liberal Association was particularly large. Three hundred women were taken by train from [[Westleigh, Greater Manchester|Westleigh]] to [[Lowton]], to be thanked for their part in MP [[Peter Raffan]]'s 1910 Parliamentary election campaign.<ref>Leigh Chronicle 12 August 1910 Wigan Archives, Leigh Town hall</ref> From 1910 to 1914 the women held tea meetings where between 100 and 200 attendees were addressed by speakers.<ref>Leigh Journal 15 November 1911 Wigan Archives, Leigh Town Hall</ref> Female Conservatives organised in either Women’s Unionist or Conservative Associations. These were large organisations, with sufficient kudos to attract the Rt Hon [[Austen Chamberlain]] MP.<ref>Leigh Journal 24 November 1911 Wigan Archives, Leigh Town Hall</ref> Though the Labour Party was in its infancy, it was formed in July 1908,<ref>Correspondence from Leigh Trades Council to the Labour Representation Committee and George Brown, Labour Party Archive, People's History Museum, Manchester</ref> it had an active women's section.<ref>Leigh Journal July 1908</ref>
==Women’s Labour League==
The [[Women's Labour League]] was a Labour Party pressure group, formed in 1906.<ref>Christine Collette, ''For Labour and for Women: The Women's Labour League 1906-1918''</ref> It promoted and supported both male and female candidates for parliamentary or municipal office and [[Boards of Guardians]].<ref>Christine Collette, For Labour and for Women: The Women's Labour League.</ref> From 1911 WLL branches were established at [[Bamfurlong, Greater Manchester|Bamfurlong]], [[Ashton in Makerfield]], [[Golborne]], [[Lowton]], Leigh and [[Tyldesley]].<ref>Women's Labour League Annual Reports WLL/1/163 to 165, Labour Party Archives, People's History Museum, Manchester</ref> The Leigh Labour Party was ambitious. Tom Greenall was its first Parliamentary candidate for the General Election of January 1910 and it was increasing its membership of Leigh Council.
==Mrs G Mottram==
The Lowton and Leigh WLL branches had a committed and able leader, Mrs G Mottram, who was a founder and secretary for the Lowton and Leigh branches.<ref>Women's Labour League Annual Reports, WLL/1.163 to 165 Labour Party Archive, People's History Museum, Manchester</ref> The branches were small, 20 in Lowton and 60 in Leigh,<ref>Women's Labour League WLL Labour Party Archive, People's Museum, Manchester</ref> but they made an impact during Leigh’s municipal elections. Mrs Mottram stood, unsuccessfully, as a candidate for Leigh Rural District Council and the Leigh Guardians' elections in 1913.<ref>Women's Labour League The League Leaflet February 1913, Labour Party Archive, People's History Museum Mancheste</ref> She attended WLL Conferences – at [[Earlestown]] she argued for equal pay for women and she was a member of the Leigh Insurance Committee.<ref>Women's Labour League Leaflet February 1913, Labour Party Archive, People's History Museum</ref> During WW1 she agitated for Municipal Lodging Houses for women munitions workers, was a member of the Leigh War Emergency Workers Committee.<ref>Borough of Leigh Minute Book, General Purposes Committee, 16 May 1916, Wigan Archives, Leigh Town Hall</ref> She was a member of Leigh’s Naval and Military War Pensions Committee and helped devise systems to aid Leigh’s Disabled Soldiers and Sailors.<ref>Women's Labour League Records, The League Leaflet February 1913 Labour Party Archive, People's History Museum, Manchester</ref>
==Facilitating working class membership==
Like [[Ellen Wilkinson]], who became a Labour MP, cabinet minister, and leader of the [[Jarrow March]]ers, working in Tyldesley,<ref>Red Ellen Wilkinson, Matt Perry</ref> Mrs Mottram was both a WLL and NUWSS organiser.<ref>Women's Labour League Annual Reports, Labour Party Archive,</ref>. In 1910 the NUWSS launched its Friends of Women's Suffrage Scheme.<ref>Sandra Stanley Holton, Feminism and Democracy: Women's Suffrage and Reform Politics 1900-1918</ref>. It enabled people who could not afford membership fees to become members simply by pledging their allegiance which widened the demographic and increased the membership. From a membership of 21,571 in 1910, by 1913 39,000 "friends" had enrolled.<ref>Sandra Stanley Holton, Feminism and Democracy: Women's Suffrage and Reform Politics in Britain 1900-1918</ref> From 200 branches in 1910 there were 602 in 1914.<ref>Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, NUWSS on line</ref> At this time NUWSS leaders, particularly in the North, increasingly identified with the working clases and for an industrial town like Leigh this was particularly pertinent.
==Leigh municipal elections 1912==
Mrs Mottram’s feminism and Labour politics came together during Leigh’s 1912 and 1913 municipal elections. Mr J L Prescott, the successful Labour candidate for St Mary’s Ward in 1912, acknowledged that the work of Mrs Mottram and the Women’s Labour League co-workers had been a big factor in his success against the Liberal J. Sargent.<ref>Leigh Chronicle 8 November 1912 Wigan Archives, Leigh Town Hall</ref> It is possible that Mrs Mottram’s co-workers were drawn from the women’s sections of all Leigh’s political parties.
In 1912 Mrs Nessie Egerton Stewart Brown, President of the Lancashire and Cheshire Women’s Liberal Association warned that its members were losing patience with the Lancashire and Cheshire Liberal Association’s refusal to discuss the question of Women’s Suffrage.<ref>Manchester Guardian Cuttings Book, Letter from Mrs Egerton Stewart Brown May 1912, John Rylands Library Manchester</ref> At the same time Leigh’s Liberal women were offered an alternative. The NUWSS, which contained a large Liberal contingent, disappointed by the Liberal Party’s continual rejection of women’s suffrage reached an agreement with the Labour Party.<ref>Leigh Journal 24 May 1912 Wigan Arches Leigh Town Hall</ref> The Labour Party was the only party to pledge its complete support for Women’s Suffrage, the NUWSS agreed to support Labour Parliamentary and municipal candidates.<ref>Leigh Journal 25 May 1912, Wigan Archives, Leigh Town Hall</ref> The Conservative Party in the main, were anti-women’s suffrage. In the 1913 St Mary’s Ward, Conservative Councillor W.R.Boydell fighting for re-election in 1913 had no women helpers, despite there being a large Women’s Unionist Association in the ward. The victor, Labour’s J.H. Wright, when praising the WLL canvassers, commented that Boydell had had to do "all the spade work himself".<ref>Leigh Journal 8 November 1913, Wigan Archives, Leigh Town Hall</ref> W.R. Boydell and George Hunter, Liberal Councillor for St Mary’s in 1911, was a proven women’s suffragist. In 1911, at the request of the NUWSS, Leigh Council was one of 146 County, Borough and District Councils , to petition Parliament in support of enfranchising women householders. In council, it was Councillor Hunter who moved the resolution with Councillor Boydell seconding.<ref>Borough of Leigh Proceedings of the Council, 1910-1911 page 185 9 May 1911</ref>
==Wider involvement==
Throughout this period the NUWSS called on its member societies to take part in the mass demonstrations and rallies. As a significant proportion of the participants were northern working women, prominent among these being [[pit brow women]] and mill workers, in all probability some Leigh women were represented. Despite details of ordinary women’s personal involvement being hard to find, there is evidence that members of the Leigh Women’s Suffrage Society spent weeks making goods to sell on the Leigh, Wigan, Farnworth and Eccles stall at the 1912 NUWSS fund-raising bazaar at the [[Midland Hotel, Manchester]].<ref>Leigh Journal February 1912, Wigan Archives, Leigh Town Hall.</ref><ref>National Union of Women's Suffrage Collection M50 Reel 3 Manchester Archives +</ref>

Loukas]]}} {{location map~ |Greece |lat=38.373906 |long=26.055739 |label=[[Nea Moni of Chios|Nea Moni]]}} {{location map~ |Greece |lat=37.733333 |long=26.833333 |label=[[Pythagoreion]] and [[Heraion of Samos|Heraion]]|position=right}} {{location map~ |Greece |lat=40.481111 |long=22.313611 |label=[[Vergina]]|position=left}} {{location map~ |Greece |lat=37.730833 |long=22.756111 |label=[[Mycenae]]|position=left}} {{location map~ |Greece |lat=37.316667 |long=26.5 |label=[[Patmos]]|position=bottom}} {{location map~ |Greece |lat=37.316667 |long=22.799722 |label=[[Tiryns]]}} {{location map~ |Greece |lat=39.616667 |long=19.916667 |label=[[Corfu (city)|Corfu]]|position=bottom}} {{location map~ |Greece |lat=38.013056 |long=23.635833 |label=[[Daphni Monastery|Daphni]]|position=left}} {{location map~ |Greece |lat=41.013056 |long=24.286389 |label=[[Philippi]]|position=top}} }} There are currently 18 [[UNESCO World Heritage sites]] in [[Greece]].{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/gr |title=Greece: Properties inscribed on the World Heritage List |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-01-13}} Of these, 16 are inscribed based on [[World Heritage site#Cultural criteria|"cultural"]] criteria, while the remaining two ([[Mount Athos]], [[Meteora]]) are inscribed for meeting both "cultural" and "natural" criteria. Five of the sites are located on [[Greek islands|islands]], one is distributed between the islands and the mainland, with the remaining 12 exclusively on the mainland. This first site to be inscribed was the [[Temple of Apollo at Bassae]] in 1986, the most recent is the [[Philippi]], inscribed in 2016. There are an additional 14 sites on the tentative list. ==World Heritage sites== The table lists information about each World Heritage site: :'''Name'''; as listed by the [[World Heritage Committee]] :'''Location'''; in one of Greece's regions, with co-ordinates provided by UNESCO :'''Period'''; time period of significance, typically of construction :'''UNESCO data'''; Site reference number, the year the site was inscribed on the World Heritage List, and the criteria it was listed under :'''Description'''; brief description of the site {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%; border:0; text-align:left; line-height:150%;" |- ! style="width:8%;"| Name ! style="width:10%;" class="unsortable"| Image ! style="width:10%;" class="unsortable"| Location ! style="width:7%;"| Date ! style="width:10%;"| UNESCO data ! style="width:55%;" class="unsortable"| Description |- | [[Acropolis of Athens|Acropolis, Athens]] | [[File:Acropolis wide view.jpg|150px]] | [[Athens]], [[Attica]]

{{coord|40.47|22.43|name=Archaeological Site of Aigai (modern name Vergina)}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/780 |title=Archaeological Site of Aigai (modern name Vergina) |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-01-13}} | 1st millennium BC | {{sort|0780|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/780 780]; 1996;
i, iii}} | The ancient city of [[Aegae (Macedon)|Aigai]] was the first capital of the Kingdom of [[Macedon]]. In addition to the monumental palace, lavishly decorated with mosaics and painted stuccoes, the site contains a burial ground with more than 300 tumuli, one of which has been identified as that of [[Philip II of Macedon]], father of [[Alexander the Great]]. |- | [[Delphi|Archeological site of Delphi]] | [[File:Columns of the Temple of Apollo at Delphi, Greece.jpeg|150px]] | [[Phocis]], [[Central Greece (region)|Central Greece]]
{{coord|38.48|22.5|name=Archeological site of Delphi}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/393 |title=Archeological site of Delphi |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-01-25}} | 8th century BC | {{sort|0393|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/393 393]; 1987;
i, ii, iii, iv, vi}} | The pan-Hellenic sanctuary of [[Delphi]], location of the [[Pythia|oracle]] of [[Apollo]], was the spiritual center of the Greek world. Situated in a spectacular natural setting at the foot of [[Mount Parnassus]], it was a symbol of Greek cultural unity from the 8th century BC onwards. |- | [[Mystras|Archeological site of Mystras]] | [[File:Mystras palace.JPG|150px]] | [[Laconia]], [[Peloponnese (region)|Peloponnese]]
{{coord|37.08|22.37|name=Archeological site of Mystras}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/511 |title=Archeological site of Mystras |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-02-07}} | 13th century AD | {{sort|0511|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/511 511]; 1989;
ii, iii, iv}} | Long known as "the Wonder of the [[Morea]]", the remarkably well-preserved medieval city of Mystras played a central role in the final years of the [[Byzantine Empire]]. Built on a steep hill at the foot of Mount [[Taygetus]], it was the last Byzantine stronghold to fall to the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomans]], holding out until 1461. |- | [[Olympia, Greece|Archeological site of Olympia]] | [[File:GR-olympia-palaestra.jpg|150px]] | [[Elis (regional unit)|Elis]], [[West Greece]]
{{coord|37.64|21.67|name=Archeological site of Olympia}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/517 |title=Archeological site of Olympia |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-02-07}} | 10th century BC | {{sort|0517|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/517 517]; 1989;
i, ii, iii, iv, vi}} | The site of Olympia, built on the banks of the [[Alpheios]] river in the [[Peloponnese]], was the location of the [[ancient Olympic Games]] beginning in 776 BC. In addition to numerous temples and sanctuaries, it contains the remains of several sporting structures, such as its famous stadium. |- | [[Mycenae|Archeological site of Mycenae and Tiryns]] | [[File:Lions-Gate-Mycenae.jpg|150px]] | [[Argolis]], [[Peloponnese (region)|Peloponnese]]
{{coord|37.64|22.75|name=Archeological site of Mycenae and Tiryns}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/941 |title=Archeological site of Mycenae and Tiryns |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-02-07}} | 15th century BC | {{sort|0941|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/941 941]; 1999;
i, ii, iii, iv, vi}} | Mycenae and Tiryns were two of the most important cities of [[Mycenean Greece]], which flourished between the 15th and 12th centuries BC. The [[Lion's Gate]] and [[Treasury of Atreus]] at Mycenae have been listed as "outstanding examples of human creative genius". |- | [[Delos]] | [[File:House of Cleopatra, Delos.jpg|150px]] | [[Cyclades]], [[South Aegean]]
{{coord|37.39|25.16|name=Delos}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/530 |title=Delos |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-02-07}} | 7th century BC | {{sort|0530|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/530 530]; 1990;
ii, iii, iv, vi}} | The birthplace of [[Apollo]] and [[Artemis]] according to Greek mythology, the sacred island of Delos was one of the most important pan-Hellenic sanctuaries. The sanctuary of Apollo on Delos attracted pilgrims from all over Greece, making Delos a prosperous trading port. |- | [[Monastery of Saint John the Theologian|Historic Centre (Chora) with the Monastery of Saint John]] | [[File:Chora di Patmos con il Monastero di San Giovanni "il teologo".JPG|150px]] | [[Patmos]], [[South Aegean]]
{{coord|37.309189|26.548053|name=Patmos}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/942 |title=Historic Centre (Chorá) with the Monastery of Saint John |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-09-30}} | 10th century | {{sort|0942|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/942 942]; 1999;
iii, iv, vi}} | The small island of [[Pátmos]] in the [[Dodecanese]] is reputed to be where [[John of Patmos|St John the Theologian]] wrote both his [[Gospel of St John|Gospel]] and the [[Apocalypse]]. A [[Monastery of Saint John the Theologian|monastery dedicated to the ‘beloved disciple’]] was founded there in the late 10th century and it has been a place of pilgrimage and [[Greek Orthodox]] learning ever since. The fine monastic complex dominates the island. The old settlement of [[Chorá]], associated with it, contains many religious and secular buildings. |- | [[Medieval City of Rhodes]] | [[File:Cour palais grand maître Rhodes.jpg|150px]] | [[Rhodes (city)|Rhodes]], [[South Aegean]]
{{coord|36.433333|28.216667|name=Rhodes}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/493 |title=Medieval City of Rhodes |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-09-30}} | | {{sort|0493|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/493 493]; 1988;
ii, iv, v}} | The [[Order of St John of Jerusalem]] occupied [[Rhodes]] from 1309 to 1523 and set about transforming the city into a stronghold. It subsequently came under Turkish and Italian rule. With the [[Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes|Palace of the Grand Masters]], the Great Hospital and the Street of the Knights, the Upper Town is one of the most beautiful urban ensembles of the [[Gothic art|Gothic period]]. In the Lower Town, Gothic architecture coexists with mosques, public baths and other buildings dating from the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] period. |- | Monasteries of [[Daphni Monastery|Daphni]], [[Hosios Loukas]] and [[Nea Moni of Chios]] | [[File:20090803 hosiosloukas12.jpg|150px]] [[File:Gotic Dafni.jpg|150px]] [[File:Nea Moni - buildings.JPG|150px]] | Hosios Loukas: [[Distomo]], [[Boeotia]]
{{coord|38.394722|22.746667|name=Hosios Loukas}}
Daphni Monastery: [[Chaidari]], [[Attica]]
{{coord|38.013056|23.635833|name=Daphni}}
Nea Moni: [[Chios]], [[North Aegean]]
{{coord|38.373906|26.055739|name=Nea Moni}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/537 |title=Monasteries of Daphni, Hosios Loukas and Nea Moni of Chios |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-09-30}} | 11th and 12th centuries | {{sort|0537|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/537 537]; 1990;
i, iv}} | Although geographically distant from each other, these three monasteries belong to the same typological series and share the same aesthetic characteristics. The churches are built on a cross-in-square plan with a large dome supported by squinches defining an octagonal space. In the 11th and 12th centuries they were decorated with superb marble works as well as mosaics on a gold background, all characteristic of the 'second golden age of [[Byzantine art]]'. |- | [[Corfu (city)|Old Town of Corfu]] | [[File:Corfu town.jpg|150px]] | [[Corfu (city)|Corfu]], [[Ionian Islands (region)|Ionian Islands]]
{{coord|39.616667|19.916667|name=Corfu}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/978 |title=Old Town of Corfu |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-09-30}} | 8th century BC | {{sort|0978|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/978 978]; 2007;
iv}} | The Old [[Corfu (city)|Town of Corfu]], on the [[Island of Corfu]] off the western coasts of [[Albania]] and Greece, is located in a strategic position at the entrance of the [[Adriatic Sea]], and has its roots in the 8th century BC. The three forts of the town, designed by renowned Venetian engineers, were used for four centuries to defend the maritime trading interests of the [[Republic of Venice]] against the [[Ottoman Empire]]. In the course of time, the forts were repaired and partly rebuilt several times, more recently under [[United States of the Ionian Islands|British rule]] in the 19th century. The mainly neoclassical housing stock of the Old Town is partly from the Venetian period, partly of later construction, notably the 19th century. As a fortified Mediterranean port, Corfu’s urban and port ensemble is notable for its high level of integrity and authenticity. |- | [[Paleochristian and Byzantine monuments of Thessaloniki]] | [[File:Ac.galerius2.jpg|150px]] | [[Thessaloniki]], [[Central Macedonia]]
{{coord|40.65|22.9|name=Thessalonika}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/456 |title=Paleochristian and Byzantine Monuments of Thessalonika |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-09-30}} | 315 B.C. | {{sort|0456|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/456 456]; 1988;
i, ii, iv}} | Founded in 315 B.C., the provincial capital and sea port of [[Thessalonika]] was one of the first bases for the spread of Christianity. Among its Christian monuments are fine churches, some built on the Greek cross plan and others on the three-nave basilica plan. Constructed over a long period, from the 4th to the 15th century, they constitute a diachronic typological series, which had considerable influence in the [[Byzantine Empire]]. |- | [[Pythagoreion]] and [[Heraion of Samos]] | [[File:Heraion of Samos.jpg|150px]] | [[Samos]], [[North Aegean]]
{{coord|37.701208|26.868783|name=Samos}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/595 |title=Pythagoreion and Heraion of Samos |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-09-30}} | 3rd millennium B.C. | {{sort|0595|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/595 595]; 1992;
ii, iii}} | Many civilizations have inhabited this small [[Aegean island]], near [[Asia Minor]], since the 3rd millennium B.C. The remains of [[Pythagoreion]], an ancient fortified port with Greek and Roman monuments and a spectacular tunnel-aqueduct, as well as the Heraion, [[Heraion of Samos|temple of the Samian Hera]], can still be seen. |- | [[Sanctuary of Asklepios at Epidaurus]] | [[File:20100408 epidaure29.JPG|150px]] | [[Epidaurus]], [[Peloponnese (region)|Peloponnese]]
{{coord|37.633333|23.133333|name=Epidaurus}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/491 |title=Sanctuary of Asklepios at Epidaurus |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-09-30}} | 4th century | {{sort|0491|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/491 491]; 1988;
i, ii, iii, iv, vi}} | In a small valley in the [[Peloponnesus]], the shrine of [[Asklepios]], the god of medicine, developed out of a much earlier cult of [[Apollo]], during the 6th century BC at the latest, as the official cult of the city state of Epidaurus. Its principal monuments, particularly the temple of Asklepios, the Tholos and the Theatre - considered one of the purest masterpieces of Greek architecture – date from the 4th century. The vast site, with its temples and hospital buildings devoted to its healing gods, provides valuable insight into the healing cults of Greek and Roman times. |- | [[Temple of Apollo Epicurius at Bassae]] | [[File:The Temple of Apollo Epikourios at Bassae, Arcadia, Greece (14250629376).jpg|150px]] | [[Bassae]], [[Messenia]], [[Peloponnese (region)|Peloponnese]]
{{coord|37.429722|21.900278|name=Bassae}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/392 |title=Temple of Apollo Epicurius at Bassae |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-09-30}} | 5th century B.C. | {{sort|0392|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/392 392]; 1986;
i, ii, iii, iv, vi}} | This famous temple to the god of healing and the sun was built towards the middle of the 5th century B.C. in the lonely heights of the [[Arcadia]]n mountains. The temple, which has the oldest [[Corinthian capital]] yet found, combines the [[Archaism|Archaic style]] and the serenity of the [[Doric style]] with some daring architectural features. |- | [[Meteora]] | [[File:Greece meteora monasteries.JPG|150px]] | near [[Kalabaka]], [[Thessaly]]
{{coord|39.714167|21.631111|name=Meteora}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/455 |title=Meteora |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-09-30}} | | {{sort|0455|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/455 455]; 1988;
i, ii, iv, v, vii}} | In a region of almost inaccessible sandstone peaks, monks settled on these 'columns of the sky' from the 11th century onwards. Twenty-four of these monasteries were built, despite incredible difficulties, at the time of the great revival of the [[eremetic]] ideal in the 15th century. Their 16th-century frescoes mark a key stage in the development of [[Post-Byzantine art|post-Byzantine]] painting. |- | [[Mount Athos]] | [[File:Esphigmenou monastery 2006.jpg|150px]] | [[Autonomous Monastic State of the Holy Mountain]]
{{coord|40.157222|24.326389|name=Mount Athos}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/454 |title=Mount Athos |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2012-09-30}} | | {{sort|0454|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/454 454]; 1988;
i, ii, iv, v, vi, vii}} | An Orthodox spiritual centre since 1054, Mount Athos has enjoyed an autonomous statute since [[Byzantine]] times. The 'Holy Mountain', which is forbidden to women and children, is also a recognized artistic site. The layout of the monasteries (about 20 of which are presently inhabited by some 1,400 monks) had an influence as far afield as [[Russia]], and its school of painting influenced the history of Orthodox art. |- | [[Philippi]] | [[File:Ancient Theatre, built by Philip II in the 4th century BC and later reconstructed by the Romans, Philippi (7272297822).jpg|Ancient Theatre, built by Philip II in the 4th century BC and later reconstructed by the Romans, Philippi (7272297822)|150px]] | [[Philippi]], [[Kavala]], [[Eastern Macedonia and Thrace|Eastern Macedonia]]
{{coord|41.013056|24.286389|name=Philippi}}{{citation |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1517 |title=Archaeological Site of Philippi |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=2016-07-15}} | 4th century B.C. - 14th century A.D | {{sort|1517|[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1517 1517]; 2016;
iii, iv}} | The remains of this walled city lie at the foot of an acropolis in the present-day region of [[Eastern Macedonia and Thrace]], on the ancient route linking Europe and Asia, the [[Via Egnatia]]. Founded in 356 BC by the Macedonian King [[Philip II of Macedon|Philip II]], the city developed as a “small Rome” with the establishment of the [[Roman Empire]] in the decades following the [[Battle of Philippi]], in 42 BCE. The [[Hellenistic]] theatre and funerary [[heroon]] (temple) were supplemented with Roman buildings such as the [[Roman Forum|forum]]. Later the city became a [[Early centres of Christianity|centre of the Christian faith]] following the visit of the [[Apostle Paul]] in 49-50 CE. The remains of its [[basilica]]s constitute an exceptional testimony to the early establishment of Christianity. |} ==Tentative list{{cite
