'''William Hickling Prescott''' (May 4, 1796 – January 28, 1859) was an American historian and [[Hispanist]], who is widely recognized by [[historiography|historiographers]] to have been the first American scientific historian. Despite suffering from serious visual impairment, which at times prevented him from reading or writing for himself, Prescott became one of the most eminent historians of 19th century America. He is also noted for his [[eidetic memory]].
After an extensive period of study, during which he sporadically contributed to academic journals, Prescott specialized in late Renaissance Spain and the early [[Spanish Empire]]. His works on the subject, ''The History of the Reign of [[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand]] and [[Isabella I of Castile|Isabella the Catholic]]'' (1837), ''The History of the Conquest of Mexico'' (1843), ''A History of the Conquest of Peru'' (1847) and the unfinished ''History of the Reign of Phillip II'' (1856–1858) have become classic works in the field, and have had a great impact on the study of both Spain and [[Mesoamerica]]. During his lifetime, he was upheld as one of the greatest living American intellectuals, and knew personally many of the leading political figures of the day, in both the United States and Britain. Prescott has become one of the most widely translated American historians, and was an important figure in the development of history as a rigorous academic discipline.<ref>Gardiner, p. ix</ref><ref>Gardiner, p. 143</ref> Historians admire Prescott for his exhaustive, careful, and systematic use of archives, his accurate recreation of sequences of events, his balanced judgments and his lively writing style. He was primarily focused on political and military affairs, largely ignoring economic, social, intellectual, and cultural forces that in recent decades historians have focused on. Instead, he wrote narrative history, subsuming unstated causal forces in his driving storyline.<ref>Robert Muccigrosso, ed., ''Research Guide to American Historical Biography'' (1988) 3:1259-61</ref>
== Early life == [[File:Statue of william prescott in charlestown massachusetts.jpg|thumb|upright|alt= A statue of a man wearing cape and hat, and holding a sword standing to the left |A bronze statue of Prescott's grandfather [[William Prescott]] in [[Charlestown, Boston|Charlestown]], [[Massachusetts]]]]
William H. Prescott was born in [[Salem, Massachusetts]] on May 4, 1796, the first of seven children, although four of his siblings died in infancy.<ref>Sullivan, 1972, p. 154</ref> His parents were [[William Prescott, Jr.]], a lawyer, and his wife, [[née]] Catherine Greene Hickling. His grandfather [[William Prescott]] served as a colonel during the [[American Revolutionary War]].<ref>Peck, p. 13</ref>
Prescott began formal schooling at the age of seven, studying under Mr. Jacob Knapp.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 3, Peck p. 16</ref> The family moved to [[Boston, Massachusetts]] in 1808, where his father's earnings substantially increased.<ref>Peck, 2009, p. 18</ref> His studies continued under Dr. John Gardiner, rector of [[Trinity Church, Boston|Trinity Episcopal Church]].<ref>Sullivan, 1972, pp. 155–156, Peck p. 18, Gardiner p. 7</ref> As a young man, Prescott frequented the [[Boston Athenæum]], which at the time held the 10,000-volume [[private library]] of [[John Quincy Adams]], who was on a diplomatic mission to [[Russia]].<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 9</ref><ref>Peck, p. 20</ref> In 1832, Prescott became a trustee of the library, a position he held for 15 years.<ref>Gardiner, p. 324</ref>
Prescott enrolled at [[Harvard College]] as a second year student ([[sophomore year|sophomore]]) in August 1811, at the age of 15.<ref>Sullivan, 1972, p. 156, Peck p. 22</ref> He was not considered academically distinguished, despite showing promise in [[Latin]] and [[Greek language|Greek]]. Prescott found mathematics particularly difficult, and resorted to memorizing mathematical demonstrations word-for-word, which he could do with relative ease, in order to hide his ignorance of the subject.<ref>Peck, p. 33</ref><ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 16</ref><ref>Gardiner, p. 20</ref> Prescott's eyesight degenerated after being hit in the eye with a crust of bread during a [[food fight]] as a student, and it remained weak and unstable throughout the rest of his life.<ref>Peck, p. 31</ref> Prescott was admitted to the [[Phi Beta Kappa Society]] as a senior, which he considered a great personal honor,<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 26, Peck p. 34</ref> and graduated from Harvard in 1814. After a short period of [[rheumatism|rheumatic]] illness, he embarked on an extended tour of Europe.
Prescott first traveled to the island of [[São Miguel Island|São Miguel]] in the [[Azores]], where his grandfather and Portuguese grandmother lived.<ref>Peck, p. 36</ref> After two weeks, he left for the cooler climate of London, where he stayed with the distinguished surgeon [[Astley Cooper]] and the [[oculist]] [[William Adams (oculist)|William Adams]].<ref>Peck, p. 37</ref> Prescott first used a [[noctograph]] while staying with Adams; the tool became a permanent feature of his life, allowing him to write independently in spite of his impaired eyesight. He visited [[Hampton Court Palace]] with future American president [[John Quincy Adams]], at the time a diplomat in London, where they saw the [[Raphael Cartoons]].<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 44</ref> In August 1816, Prescott traveled to Paris, but later moved on to Italy, where he spent the winter. He returned to Paris in early 1817, where he chanced to meet the American [[Hispanist]] [[George Ticknor]], and made another visit to England. Prescott spent some time in [[Cambridge]], where he saw the manuscripts of [[Isaac Newton]]'s works, and returned to the United States in the same year.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 49</ref> Prescott's first academic work, an essay submitted anonymously, was rejected by the ''[[North American Review]]'' in late 1817.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 51</ref> After a short period of courtship, he married Susan Amory, the daughter of [[Thomas Coffin Amory]] and Hannah Rowe Linzee, on May 4, 1820.<ref>Peck, p. 43</ref>
== Career == === Early career: The ''History of Ferdinand and Isabella'' === In 1821, Prescott abandoned the idea of a legal career because of the continued deterioration of his eyesight, and resolved to devote himself to literature.<ref>Peck, p. 44</ref> Although he initially studied a wide range of subjects, including Italian, French, English and Spanish literature, [[History of North America|American history]], [[classics]] and [[political philosophy]], Prescott came to focus on [[Italian poetry]].<ref>Gardiner, p. 71</ref> Among the works he studied during this period were such classics as [[Dante]]'s ''[[La Divina Commedia|Divine Comedy]]'' and [[Boccacio]]'s ''[[Decameron]]''. His first published works were two essays in the ''North American Review''—both discussing Italian poetry. The first of these, published in 1824,<ref>Peck, p. 46</ref> was titled ''Italian Narrative Poetry'', and became somewhat controversial after it was heavily criticized in an Italian review by [[Lorenzo Da Ponte]], the librettist of [[Mozart]]'s [[Don Giovanni]].<ref>Rossi, Joseph ''The Italian Poems of Thomas James Mathias'', 1943, printed in ''[[Modern Language Quarterly]]'', p. 331</ref> Prescott wrote a succinct reply to Da Ponte's fifty-page argument in the ''North American Review'' of July 1825. Da Ponte published the criticisms as an appendix to his translation of [[Robert Dodsley|Dodley]]'s ''Economy of Human life'', which resulted in Prescott noticing them rather late.<ref name="Ticknor, 1864, p. 249">Ticknor, 1864, p. 249</ref>
Prescott first became interested in the history of Spain after his friend, the Harvard professor George Ticknor, sent him copies of his lectures on the subject.<ref>Peck, p. 48</ref> Prescott's studies initially remained broad, but he started preparing material on [[Catholic Monarchs|Ferdinand and Isabella]] in January 1826.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 76</ref> His acquaintance [[Pascual de Gayangos y Arce]] helped him construct a sizable personal library of historical books and manuscripts concerning the subject. [[Alexander Hill Everett]], an American diplomat in Spain, also provided him with material which was unavailable to Prescott in Boston.<ref>Herring, p. 3</ref> However, progress was stalled almost immediately, due to a sudden deterioration in Prescott's eyesight. Unable to find a reader fluent in Spanish, Prescott was forced to work through Spanish texts with an assistant who did not understand the language.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 81</ref> When Alexander Everett heard of this situation, he provided Prescott with the services of [[George Lunt]], who had adequate knowledge of Spanish for the task. However, this could only be a temporary arrangement, and he was replaced by a man named Hamilton Parker, who held the position for a year.<ref>Gardiner, p. 87</ref> Eventually George Ticknor, who was by then in charge of the department of modern literature at Harvard University, found James L. English, who worked with Prescott until 1831.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 82</ref> Among the books studied by Prescott in this period, Ticknor lists [[Juan Antonio Llorente]]'s ''Historia crítica de la Inquisición de España'', ''Historia de los Reyes Católicos don Fernando y doña Isabel'' by {{ill|Andrés Bernáldez|es}}, [[Voltaire]]'s ''[[History of Charles XII|Charles XII]]'' and [[William Roscoe]]'s ''Life of Lorenzo de Medici'', which were to be the sources on which the ''History of Ferdinand and Isabella'' was to be based.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 89</ref> In spring 1828, Prescott visited Washington, where he and Ticknor dined with [[John Quincy Adams]] at the [[White House]], and saw Congress in session.<ref>Gardiner, p. 93</ref>
Due in part to his own condition, Prescott was interested in aiding the blind and partially sighted. The [[Perkins School for the Blind]], then known as the New England Asylum, had been founded in [[Boston, Massachusetts]] by [[Samuel Gridley Howe]], [[Thomas Handasyd Perkins]] and [[John Dix Fisher]] and 28 others in 1829.<ref>Gardiner, p. 108</ref> Prescott involved himself from the very start of the project, becoming a [[trustee]] in 1830. He published an article in support of [[education for the blind]] in the ''North American Review'' of July 1830, and helped to raise $50,000 for the organization in May 1833.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 253</ref><ref>Gardiner, p. 119</ref>
[[File:History of Ferdinand and Isabella 1838 title pages.jpg|thumb|left|alt=An open book, showing an image of Ferdinand and Isabella enthroned|Title pages of the ''History of [[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand]] and [[Isabella I of Castile|Isabella]]'', 1838 edition]] His work was disturbed in February 1829 by the unexpected death of his eldest daughter Catherine, who was only four years old. This led him to reconsider his position on religion—previously an [[agnostic]], his interest in Christianity was renewed, and having read the [[Bible]], the works of the theologian [[William Paley]] as well as more skeptical works such as [[David Hume|Hume's]] ''[[Of Miracles]]'', he came to acknowledge the "moral truth" of the gospels, while remaining opposed to the doctrines of orthodox Christianity.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, pp. 91, 152.</ref> Despite this personal tragedy, and his own continued ill health, Prescott had gathered sufficient material to begin drafting the ''History'' in October 1829.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 94</ref> At around this time, Prescott read the works of [[Gabriel Bonnot de Mably]], including his historiographical piece ''De l’étude de l’histoire''. He henceforth aimed to write history to de Mably's romantic ideal, and on more than one occasion expressed his indebtedness to him.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p.95</ref> Prescott also encountered ''Elogia de la Réina Doña Isabel'', by his Spanish contemporary [[Diego Clemencín]], which helped shape his views concerning the monarchs' political roles. Due to further problems with his eyesight, it took him sixteen months to write the first three hundred pages of the ''History''. It was largely finished by 1834, but Prescott dedicated two years to [[abridgement|abridging]] and redrafting it. He was also briefly engaged in writing a biography of [[Charles Brockden Brown]] for [[Jared Sparks]]' ''Library of American Biography''.<ref>Gardiner, p. 121</ref> Prescott was not familiar with American literature, and he based the work on other contemporary biographies of Brown. As a result, the biography has had little academic impact. In 1835, he took residence in the rural town of [[Nahant, Massachusetts]], due to concerns about his health.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 99</ref> He was here accustomed to riding his horses for the purpose of exercise, and he persevered even in sub-zero temperatures.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 127</ref> Prescott finished the concluding chapter of the work in July 1836, and despite the amount of time and effort which he had spent on the work, was at first unsure about publishing it. However, his father argued that refusing to do so would amount to cowardice, and this swayed him.<ref>Griswold, 1847, p. 372</ref> Prescott had previously considered publishing the work in London first, and therefore a printed draft copy of the work was sent to a [[Thomas Aspinwall (consul)|Colonel Aspinwall]] for consideration.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 109</ref> However, both [[Longman]] and Murray, which were at the time the leading British publishers, refused the work, and Prescott decided to postpone.
The ''History of Ferdinand and Isabella'' was published on Christmas Day, 1837 by the American Stationery Company, [[Boston]], with a print run of 500 copies.<ref>Gardiner, p. 138</ref> It was dedicated to his father. To the surprise of Prescott and the publisher, the book sold very well—the original print run was insufficient to adequately supply Boston's bookshops, let alone the whole nation's.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 106</ref><ref>Gardiner, p. 141</ref> It was first published in London by [[Richard Bentley (publisher)|Richard Bentley]] in early 1838. The work received excellent critical reviews, both in America and in Britain, where [[Henry Vassall-Fox]] and [[Robert Southey]] expressed their admiration of the work.<ref name="Gardiner, p. 142">Gardiner, p. 142</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Review of ''History of Ferdinand and Isabella'' by William H. Prescott|journal=The Quarterly Review|date=June 1839|volume=64|pages=1–58|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=iau.31858021738798;view=1up;seq=15}}</ref> It was also noticed in France, despite the fact that a French translation was not available at the time.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 112</ref> Prescott was adamant that his work should not be altered by anyone other than himself, and when he heard that his publishers were considering an abridgement of the ''History of Ferdinand and Isabella'' in June 1839, he produced an abridgement of the work himself, which resulted in the original project's cancellation.<ref name="Ticknor, 1864, p. 197">Ticknor, 1864, p. 197</ref> He was elected a member of the [[American Antiquarian Society]] in May 1839.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanantiquarian.org/memberlist|title=MemberList|publisher=}}</ref>
=== The ''History of the Conquest of Mexico'' === Prescott expressed interest in his correspondence in writing a biography of [[Molière]], and Ticknor records that he sent Prescott "a collection of about 50 volumes" of relevant material.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p.162</ref> However, after writing to [[Ángel Calderón de la Barca y Belgrano|Ángel Calderón de la Barca]], a Spanish minister living in Mexico, who was able to provide source material, Prescott started research on what was to become the ''History of the Conquest of Mexico''.<ref>Gardiner, p. 148</ref> He extensively read the works of [[Alexander von Humboldt]], who had written on [[Mesoamerica]], and started corresponding with the historian [[Washington Irving]], the Swiss writer [[Sismondi]] and the French historian [[Jacques Nicolas Augustin Thierry]].<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 176-8</ref><ref>Gardiner, p. 149</ref> He also received assistance in collecting sources from a college friend, Middleton, and a Dr. Lembke. In contrast to the lengthy time spent researching the ''History of Ferdinand and Isabella'', Prescott started drafting the ''History of the Conquest of Mexico'' in October 1839. However, Prescott faced difficulties in writing the work which he had not encountered previously. There was relatively little scholarship on [[Aztec]] civilization, and Prescott dismissed much of it as "speculation", and he therefore had to rely almost exclusively on primary sources (with the exception of Humboldt). In particular, he considered [[Edward King, Viscount Kingsborough|Edward King]]'s theory that the pre-Columbian civilizations were non-indigenous to be fallacious, although he was greatly indebted to him for his anthology of [[Aztec codices]] in the [[Antiquities of Mexico]].<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 195</ref> Prescott also studied Spanish writers contemporary to the conquest, most significantly [[Fray Juan de Torquemada|Torquemada]] and [[Toribio de Benavente]].<ref>Gardiner, p. 150</ref>
[[Image:Harper's monthly magazine. Image of William H. Prescott.png|alt=A page from a 19th-century magazine with a picture of a bust of a man wearing a toga and facing right|thumb|left|Depiction of Greenough's bust of Prescott in the June 1850 edition of ''Harper's new monthly magazine'']] Prescott received three honorary degrees in this period—an [[honorary doctorate]] in laws from [[Columbia University]] in autumn 1840, the [[College of William and Mary]] in July 1841 and [[South Carolina College]] in December 1841.<ref>Gardiner, p. 181</ref> He also helped [[Frances Erskine Inglis, 1st Marquise of Calderón de la Barca|Frances Inglis]] find a publisher for her autobiographical work ''Life in Mexico''.<ref>Gardiner, p. 192</ref> Moreover, [[Frances Erskine Inglis, 1st Marquise of Calderón de la Barca|Frances Inglis]] was one of Prescott's most valuable correspondents during the writing of the "History of the Conquest of Mexico." She is cited by Prescott five times throughout the text, and is described by him as, "one of the most delightful of modern traveller's."<ref>Leask, Nigel, “The Ghost in Chapultepec: Fanny Calderón de la Barca, William Prescott and Nineteenth-Century Mexican Travel Accounts”, in [[Jas Elsner]] and Joan-Pau Rubiés, Voyages & Visions. Towards a Cultural History of Travel, London Reaktion Books, 1999, pp. 205-206.</ref> Prescott found it difficult to evaluate Mesoamerican scientific and mathematical achievements, because of his relative ignorance of those subjects.<ref name="Ticknor, 1864, p. 197"/><ref>Gardiner, p. 162</ref> While working in Boston in 1841, he met [[George Howard, 7th Earl of Carlisle|George Howard]], who was to stay a close friend for the remainder of his life. Prescott worked industriously throughout 1840–1842, and as a result, the work was finished by August 1843. It was published by [[Harper & Brothers]], New York in December, Bentley issuing the British edition.<ref>Gardiner, p. 197</ref> His elderly father had suffered a stroke in October, which resulted in temporary paralysis, so Prescott spent most of the winter attending him in [[Pepperell, Massachusetts|Pepperell]]. The ''History of the Conquest of Mexico'' was received extremely well, both critically and by the general public, despite Prescott's fears to the contrary.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 205</ref> Those praising the work included [[George Hillard]] in the ''North American Review'', [[George Ticknor Curtis]] in the [[Christian Examiner]], [[Joseph Cogswell]] in the ''Methodist Quarterly'', as well as the [[Dean of St. Paul's]], [[Henry Hart Milman]]<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 206</ref> in the ''Quarterly Review''.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Review of ''The History of Mexico'' by William H. Prescott|date=December 1843|journal=The Quarterly Review|volume=73|pages=187–235|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=hvd.32044015705015;view=1up;seq=203}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Milman, Arthur|title=Henry Hart Milman|year=1900|pages=174–175|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WRAMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA174}}</ref>
=== The ''Conquest of Peru'' === In 1844, Prescott was painted by [[Joseph Alexander Ames]], and also commissioned a bust from [[Richard Saltonstall Greenough]].<ref>Gardiner, p. 213</ref> He was not active in researching for the ''Conquest of Peru'' until spring 1844, although he had already decided to write a work concerning [[Inca]] civilization while researching pre-Columbian Mexico, and listened to [[Inca Garcilaso de la Vega]]'s ''Comentarios Reales de los Incas''.<ref name="Ticknor, 1864, p. 233">Ticknor, 1864, p. 233</ref> He further studied [[Pedro Cieza de León]]'s ''Crónicas del Perú'', the works of [[Pedro Sarmiento de Gamboa]] and [[Diego Fernández]]'s ''Primera y segunda parte de la Historia del Piru''.<ref name="Ticknor, 1864, p. 233"/> Prescott's progress was stalled by the unexpected death of his brother Edward at sea. His daughter Elizabeth was seriously ill, so Prescott and his family traveled to [[Niagara, New York|Niagara]], which he considered a more healthy environment for her.<ref>Gardiner, p. 218</ref> After her recovery, they returned to Nahant in the summer, where Prescott started drafting the ''Conquest'', and, as was his custom, spent the autumn in Peperell.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 234</ref> Prescott's father died at the age of 82 on December 8, which deeply upset him.<ref>Gardiner, p. 223</ref> He took a two-month break from writing to support his widowed mother and settle matters concerning his father's estate.<ref name="Ticknor, 1864, p. 238">Ticknor, 1864, p. 238</ref> His father left numerous stocks, shares and property that amounted to $343,736.86, almost all of which was shared between Prescott and his sister.<ref>Gardiner, 225</ref> Prescott was elected to the [[Institut de France]] in February 1845, in recognition of his accomplishments as a historian.<ref name="Ticknor, 1864, p. 238"/><ref>Bibliographie de la France, Beuchot, 1846, p. 171</ref> He took the place of [[Martín Fernández de Navarrete]], who had died the previous year, after a vote was cast. He was also admitted to the [[Prussian Academy of Sciences]] in [[Berlin]].<ref name="Ticknor, 1864, p. 238"/> In the summer of 1845, a collection of articles Prescott had published in the ''North American Review'' were published as ''Biographical and Critical Miscellanies'' by Bentley in [[octavo]], and an edition was also prepared simultaneously by Harper & Brothers in New York.<ref name="Ticknor, 1864, p. 249"/><ref>Gardiner, p. 241</ref> Prescott was writing 12 pages of the work per day in the summer of 1845, and completed the first two chapters of the ''Conquest''.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 259</ref> He used the inheritance from his father to buy [[Headquarters House (Boston, Massachusetts)|a house]] on [[Beacon Street]] in Boston.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 262</ref> The building is now a [[National Historic Landmark]], and is also known as the William Hickling Prescott House.<ref name=dames>{{cite web|url=http://www.nscda.org/ma/william_hickling_prescott_house.htm|title=William Hickling Prescott House|publisher=The National Society of The Colonial Dames of America|accessdate=2009-01-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201123404/http://www.nscda.org/ma/william_hickling_prescott_house.htm|archivedate=2009-02-01|df=}}</ref><ref name="NHL Program">{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=574&ResourceType=Building|title=Prescott, William H., House|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|work=National Historic Landmarks Program|accessdate=2010-09-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606175045/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=574&ResourceType=Building|archivedate=2011-06-06|df=}}</ref> Prescott moved into the house during December 1845, and set himself a year to finish the ''Conquest of Peru''. In March, his eyesight, which had recovered significantly, suddenly deteriorated. Prescott was also suffering from acute [[dyspepsia]] and [[rheumatism]], and he travelled to Nahant to "benefit from the sea-air".<ref name="Ticknor, 1864, p. 265">Ticknor, 1864, p. 265</ref> This did not prevent him travelling to Washington, where he dined at the White House with President [[James K. Polk]]. He was also entertained by [[John Y. Mason]], the former [[United States Secretary of the Navy]], who informed him that a copy of Prescott's ''Conquest of Mexico'' had been placed in the library of every fighting ship.<ref>Gardiner, p. 249</ref> The ''Conquest of Peru'' was completed in March 1847. As with previous works, it was published by Harper & Brothers in the United States and Bentley in Britain. The original US print run was 7,500 copies, and the books were sold for $1 each.<ref name="Ticknor, 1864, p. 265"/><ref>Gardiner, p. 262</ref> It was translated into Spanish, French, German and Dutch, and sold excellently. As with his previous works, it was also well-received critically.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 266</ref>
=== Research on Philip II === Shortly after the publication of the ''Conquest of Peru'', Prescott turned his mind to writing a history of [[Philip II of Spain]], which he had been contemplating for several years.<ref>Gardiner, p. 279</ref> [[John Lothrop Motley]], who planned to write an independent work on the subject, was aided by Prescott, who gave him access to his library.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 280</ref> Although the two corresponded, there seems to have been little collaboration on their respective works. Prescott had started searching for sources as early as 1842, but a number of difficulties confronted him in his study of Philip II. The principal archives of historical material were held in [[Simancas]], but neither Lembke (who had collected materials for the ''Conquest of Mexico'') nor Middleton were able to gain access to them.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 285</ref> They had been informed that the library was so disordered as to make productive research impossible, even if access had been gained. However, Lembke, who as a diplomat had been expelled from Spain, made the acquaintance of two wealthy Parisian scholars, [[François Mignet|Mignet]] and Ternaux-Compans, who offered him access to their manuscript collections.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 286</ref> Furthermore, de Gayangos assisted greatly by locating important documents in the British Museum and in the collection of the [[bibliomaniac]] [[Thomas Phillipps]], who owned around 60,000 manuscripts. He also borrowed several manuscripts from the archives in Brussels, having received letters from the respected Belgian diplomat [[Sylvain Van de Weyer]] in London. de Gayangos became Professor of [[Arabic literature]] at the [[Complutense University of Madrid]] in late 1842, and subsequently lent Prescott rare books and manuscripts from the university library.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 288</ref> By the summer of 1848, Prescott had over 300 works on the subject at his disposal, but he continued to have serious problems with his eyesight; an examination by an oculist confirmed that there was untreatable damage to his retina.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 281</ref> Prescott had been commissioned by the [[Massachusetts Historical Society]] to write a biography of the scholar John Pickering in 1848, which he wrote for publication later in that year.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 283</ref> Prescott was invited to write a history of the [[Mexican–American War]], but declined, as he was uninterested in writing on contemporary events.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 291</ref>
Prescott's main secondary source for the history was [[Leopold von Ranke]]'s ''Fürste und Völker von Süd-Europa im sechzehnten und siebzehnten Jahrhundert'', a comprehensive work which included a detailed history of the [[papacy]]. Prescott admired Ranke's empirical [[historical method]], and considered his work to be the best of his predecessors on the subject.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 289</ref> He had four copies of the relevant sections of the work reprinted in a large typeface so he could read it without assistance.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 290</ref> He had made a broad plan of the work by February 1849. Prescott started writing the draft on July 26.<ref>Gardiner, p. 283</ref> At this time, Prescott was a creditor of [[John White Webster]], the chemist and murderer, and he was subsequently involved in his trial.<ref>Gardiner, p. 293-4</ref>
=== Visits to Washington and Europe === [[Image:William H. Prescott.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A scratched, half-length photographic portrait of a middle aged man in formal mid-19th century dress, facing left |right|Daguerreotype portrait of Prescott by M.B. Brady, c. 1848–1850]] Prescott visited [[Washington D.C.]] in spring 1850, where he met [[Zachary Taylor]], then President of the United States, as well as numerous other prominent figures, including [[Henry Bulwer]], the British ambassador, and [[Daniel Webster]], the former [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]], who had been a friend of Prescott's father.<ref>Gardiner, p. 298</ref> Soon afterward, he decided to visit England. He embarked from New York on May 22, and arrived at Liverpool on June 3.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 300</ref> There he stayed with an old friend, Alexander Smith, and became reacquainted with Mary Lyell, the wife of the geologist [[Charles Lyell]].<ref name="Gardiner, p. 305">Gardiner, p. 305</ref> He traveled with the Lyells to London, where they stayed in [[Mivart's Hotel]]. Prescott was greeted in London, as in Washington, by the most important members of society—he dined with the [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] and future [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Henry Temple]], the former Prime Minister [[Robert Peel]], as well as the elderly [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Duke of Wellington]].<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 303</ref> He went to the races at [[Ascot Racecourse|Ascot]], and was presented at court to [[Queen Victoria]].<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 309</ref> On June 22, he traveled to Oxford to receive an honorary doctorate in law. In Oxford, he stayed at [[Cuddesdon Palace]], the home of the [[Bishop of Oxford]], [[Samuel Wilberforce]], who was absent because of the christening of the infant [[Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn|Prince Arthur]].<ref name="Gardiner, p. 305"/><ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 310</ref> Prescott met [[Spencer Compton, 2nd Marquess of Northampton|Spencer Compton]], the president of the [[Royal Society]], who was also receiving an honorary degree.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 312</ref> He left London for Paris, where he arrived on July 20. Two days later, he traveled to Brussels, where he stayed in [[Coudenberg]], the site of a residence of the Holy Roman Emperor [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]], returning to London on July 29.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 323</ref> Traveling north, Prescott visited [[Alnwick Castle]] and the ruins of Hulm Abbey in [[Northumbria]]. On his arrival in Edinburgh, he met the geologists [[Adam Sedgwick]] and [[Roderick Murchison]], whom he accompanied to [[Inveraray]], where he visited [[Inveraray Castle]].<ref>Gardiner, p. 311</ref> Prescott then traveled south, through [[Staffordshire]], where he was entertained by [[George Sutherland-Leveson-Gower, 2nd Duke of Sutherland|George Sutherland-Leveson-Gower]]. He embarked for New York on September 14, arriving on September 27.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 338</ref>
=== Final works === Prescott spent the winter in Boston, and returned to the composition of his work. He gradually changed the focus of the ''History'', deciding that he was a better writer of history than biography<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 347</ref> and worked solidly for the next two years, alternating between Boston and Nahant. This period was interrupted only by the marriage of his daughter Elizabeth in early 1852.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 400</ref> Her husband was James Alexander; they settled in a house near the family home in Pepperell. Prescott's mother fell ill on May 17 and died soon after, which caused Prescott to fall into a bout of depression that lasted until the winter.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 384</ref> He returned to his work, and continued at the pace that he was able through the remainder of 1852 and 1853, which passed uneventfully. Prescott started to suffer seriously from rheumatism during the former year, and as a result he abandoned his residence at Nahant.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 390</ref> He bought a house in the then rural town of [[Lynn, Massachusetts]], where he was visited by Charles Lyell and his family in June 1853.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 402</ref> On August 22, he finished the second volume of the ''History''.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 403</ref> The first two volumes were finished by May 1855, but not immediately published.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 404</ref> Changes in [[British copyright law]] and a change of publishers caused Prescott to delay publication until November. Compared to his previous works, the ''History'' received little coverage in the press or in academic journals. It was suggested to him at this time that he should write a biography of Charles V, but he declined, as he regarded the work of [[William Robertson (historian)|William Robertson]] on the subject to be definitive.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 406</ref> However, he wrote an appendix to Robertson's ''The History of the reign of Charles V'' in May 1855; it was published in December 1856. Previously uninterested in politics (although he had predicted the [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig]] victory in [[United States presidential election, 1840|1840]],<ref>Gardiner, p. 166</ref>) Prescott supported and voted for the Republican [[John C. Frémont]] in the [[United States presidential election, 1856|1856 Presidential election]].<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 359</ref> He continued to work on the third volume of the ''History'' until he suffered a [[stroke]] on 3 February 1858.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 424</ref> Prescott recovered, but his health was permanently affected, and he decided to temporarily retire from writing. The third volume was therefore published in April, and its scope was more limited than Prescott had originally planned.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 428</ref> He worked on the Spanish translation of the ''Conquest of Mexico'', which had been prepared by [[José Fernando Ramírez]] and [[Lucas Alamán]].<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 429</ref>
== Personal life == William H. Prescott and Susan Amory Prescott (c. 1799 – 1859) had four children; the first, Catherine Prescott (23 September 1824 – 1 February 1829) died of a childhood illness. William Gardiner Prescott (27 January 1826 – 15 August 1895) attended Harvard from 1841 to 1844 and worked as a lawyer in Boston. He married Josephine Augusta Peabody on 6 November 1851, and inherited Headquarters House.<ref name=MVR>''Massachusetts Vital Records'', 1841–1910, Vol: 527; pp 33–37. New England Historic Genealogical Society, 2007</ref> William Gardiner's daughter Catherine Elizabeth Prescott married a Hebert Timmins on 22 February 1887.<ref>{{cite news|title=Notable Wedding in Boston|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1887/02/23/104008593.pdf|accessdate=31 August 2010|newspaper=New York Times|date=22 February 1887}}</ref> Elizabeth (27 July 1828 – 24 May 1864) married James Lawrence, a distant cousin.<ref>{{cite book |last=Lawrence |first=Robert |title=The descendant of Major Samuel Lawrence |year=1904 |publisher=Riverside Press |page=153 |url=https://archive.org/stream/descendantsofmaj00lawr/descendantsofmaj00lawr_djvu.txt}}</ref> The youngest was William Amory (25 January 1830 – 13 March 1867).<ref name=MVR/>
== Death and legacy == [[File:55 BeaconSt Boston.png|thumb|left|alt=A large house, in an American neo-classical style|Prescott lived on [[Beacon Street]], Boston, 1845–1859.<ref>State Street Trust Company. Forty of Boston's historic houses. 1912.</ref>]] In January 1859, Prescott decided to resume his work on Philip II, with the goal of writing a final fourth volume. On January 29, he suffered a second stroke, which resulted in his immediate death.<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 443</ref> He was buried with his parents in St. Paul's Church, and his funeral was attended by representatives, among others, of [[Harvard University]], the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] and the [[Essex Institute]].<ref>Ticknor, 1864, p. 446</ref>
Prescott's work has remained popular and influential to the present day, and his meticulous use of sources, [[citation|bibliographical citations]] and critical notes was unprecedented among American historians.<ref name="Gardiner, p. 142"/> As the work of an amateur historian, the ''History of Ferdinand and Isabella'' was an outstanding achievement, and it arguably was the best English-language work on the subject published until then.<ref>Gardiner, p. 144</ref> The major problems with the work to the modern day historian are not related to the quality of the research or Prescott's understanding of the period, but rather that his focus is on the major political and military events as opposed to social and economic conditions. It has also been argued that Prescott partially subscribed to the [[Great Man theory]].<ref>Commager, p. 324</ref> The ''Conquest of Mexico'' has endured more than any other of Prescott's work: it is regarded as his greatest literary accomplishment.<ref>Gardiner, p. 208</ref><ref>Peck, p. 133-6</ref> However, modern scholarship agrees that there are problems with Prescott's characterization of the conquest. David Levin has argued that the Conquest shows "inadequate attention to detail" and remains a broad and general account of events.<ref>Levin, David, "History as Romantic Art: Structure, Characterization and Style in ''The Conquest of Mexico''", ''[[Hispanic American Historical Review]]'', 39 (February 1959), pp. 20-40.</ref> In contrast to the ''Conquest of Mexico'', the ''Conquest of Peru'' has received relatively little modern scholarly attention, perhaps due to some key similarities in style and structure.<ref>Gardiner, p. 265</ref> However, it is generally thought that the work was the authoritative account until the 20th century, and that Prescott used a broader range of source material than any previous writer on the subject.<ref>Gardiner, p. 267</ref> However, the [[archeological]] and [[anthropology|anthropological]] aspects of both works have been heavily criticized by historians since the end of the 19th century. Prescott had never visited archeological sites in Mesoamerica and his understanding of [[Inca]] and [[Aztec]] culture was weak.<ref>Gardiner, p. 268</ref> In defense of Prescott, it has been argued that despite advances in archeological understanding, and a reconceptualization of the nature of pre-Columbian society, the works remain broadly historically accurate, and Prescott's elaborations on fact were due to a fundamental lack of source material.<ref>Gardiner, p. 269</ref><ref>Commager, p. 325</ref> In contrast, ''Phillip the Second'' is considered essentially an inferior piece—it lacks the epic structure and literary merits of Prescott's other work, and the work has not received more critical attention than other contemporary accounts of the monarch's life.<ref>Gardiner, p. 332</ref>
There is a popular misconception that Prescott was completely blind, which seems to have stemmed from a misunderstanding of his comment in the preface to ''The Conquest of Mexico'', in which he stated, "Nor have I ever corrected, or even read, my own original draft".<ref>Gardiner, p. 211.</ref> The myth was further propagated by a contemporary New York review of the ''Conquest'', and has been a common theme in popular accounts of his work. Other related embellishments of Prescott's disability have also occurred—[[Samuel Eliot Morison]], writing in a 1959 article for ''[[The Atlantic Monthly]]'', claimed that Prescott had an artificial eye, although there is no evidence to suggest this. It has been argued that Prescott's biographers have naturally been drawn to romanticize his life due to Prescott's own romantic style of history.<ref>Eipper, p. 417</ref>
Four biographies of Prescott have been written. In 1864, [[George Ticknor]] published a biography based on Prescott's then-unpublished correspondence, to which the later biographers have been greatly indebted. [[Rollo Ogden]]'s 1904 account is more a stylistic modernization of Ticknor's work. [[Harry Thurston Peck]]'s 1905 account is considered academically inferior due to its essentially derivative nature.<ref>Gardiner, p. xi</ref> C. Harvey Gardiner's 1969 work<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=UCdMAgAAQBAJ&dq | title=William Hickling Prescott: A Biography | publisher=[[University of Texas Press]] | author=C. Harvey Gardiner | year=2013 | pages=390 | isbn=0292735154}}</ref> is considered the definitive critical biography of Prescott, taking into account a wide range of unpublished documents that were unavailable to earlier biographers.<ref name="Gardiner Review">{{cite journal | url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-latin-american-studies/article/gardiner-c-harvey-william-hickling-prescott-a-biography-introduction-by-allan-nevins-austin-university-of-texas-press-1969-750-pp-xxi-366/3A2EC753B50DF22D1C3DB3CF94E6E57C | title=Gardiner C. Harvey: William Hickling Prescott. A Biography. Introduction by Allan Nevins | author=Humphreys, R. A. | authorlink = Robin Humphreys| journal=[[Journal of Latin American Studies]] | year=November 1971 | volume=3 | issue=2 | pages=204 | doi=10.1017/S0022216X00001462 | publisher=Cambridge Core}}</ref>
The City of [[Prescott, Arizona|Prescott]] in Arizona was named in his honor,<ref>{{cite book |title=Arizona Place Names |last=Barnes |first=Will Croft |year=1960 |publisher=[[University of Arizona Press]] |page=354 |location=Tucson, Arizona |oclc=479862}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Arizona's Names: X Marks the Place |last=Granger |first=Byrd H. |year=1983 |publisher=Falconer Publishing Company |isbn=978-0-918080-18-9 |page=500}}</ref> as was the William H. Prescott House (Headquarters House), which was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] for its association with him.<ref name="dames" /><ref name="NHL Program" /> [[Colegio Anglo Americano Prescott]], a school in [[Arequipa|Arequipa, Peru]], also bears his name.<ref>{{cite web |author=MDB |url=http://www.prescott.edu.pe/guia/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=15&Itemid=29 |title=Nuestro Proyecto Educativo |date=2008-02-23 |publisher=Guía Educativa |accessdate=2010-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090705184240/http://www.prescott.edu.pe/guia/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=15&Itemid=29 |archivedate=July 5, 2009 }}</ref> Prescott Street, two blocks from [[Harvard Yard]] in Cambridge, Massachusetts, is named after him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hul.harvard.edu/lib/archives/refshelf/cba/p.html#prescottst|title=Harvard/Radcliffe On-line Historical Reference Shelf: Cambridge Buildings|publisher=}}</ref>
Historian Richard Kagan has identified "Prescott's Paradigm" as a 19th century interpretive model first fully articulated by Prescott. It argues that Spain's early modern 'decline' and subsequent 'torpor' was a product of its religious bigotry and political despotism. The Prescott Paradigm was dominant in 20th century American historiography, But was showing signs of decline by the 1990s.<ref>Richard L. Kagan, "Prescott's Paradigm: American Historical Scholarship and the Decline of Spain." ''American Historical Review'' 101#2 (1996): 423-446.</ref> Kagan wrote: :What I call "Prescott's paradigm" is an understanding of Spain as the antithesis of the United States. Most of the elements contained in this paradigm — anti-Catholicism, criticism of absolutism, support for commerce and individual liberty — were to be found in the work of other writers, but Prescott bundled them into a single package that offered a means of approaching Spanish history through the lens of that of U.S. history.<ref>{{cite book|author=Richard L. Kagan|title=Spain in America: The Origins of Hispanism in the United States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qq-w4POa8ikC&pg=PA253|year=2002|publisher=U of Illinois Press|page=253}}</ref>

{{italic title}} The '''''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft'' (ZDMG)''', lit. "Journal of the German Oriental Society", is a journal of [[Oriental studies]], published by the [[Deutsche Morgenländische Gesellschaft]] since 1847.
==Digitisation== The journal has been [[digitizing|digitized]] and is available at no cost from the [[University of Halle]].<ref>[http://menadoc.bibliothek.uni-halle.de/dmg/periodical/structure/2327 University of Halle] Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft : ZDMG Wiesbaden : Harrassowitz, 1847-M</ref> The journal is available from 1847–2007, together with various indexes and supplements, including the Deutscher Orientalistentag volumes from 1968–1995.
